reviewText: When I was young, I remember one day I was playing with my lego, my dad came home with a gift for me. It was a disc version of Sonic Adventure DX. I had only played Sonic The Hedgehog on my Sega Mega Drive. I was so excited to play this I immediately installed it on our family computer. I had many fun hours playing this game. But on one cold raining day, I woke up ready to play some more, for I was almost finshed. But as I walked into the office, I saw the disc smashed to pieces on the floor. I ran to my dad in tears. We never found out how it broke. For many weeks I would cry myself to sleep. My dad tryed to find anothe copy. But ever time he went to the shops, it would end in failure. Many years passed and I now play other games to hide my sadness. But as I'm browsing the steam store, I see a game called Sonic Adventure DX" It was like Jesus himself kissed me on the face. I then bought the game and my childhood was brought back from the dead. This game was my childhood and when it broke
date: it took my childhood. I feel like a happy little boy again."

reviewText:
...for the retro gamers.

The game got released in 2003, and the original on Dreamcast in 1999. So consider this game old.
Now it all depends of your age, if you are between 12-17 years old, I don't recommend you this unless as said on the title, if you are a retro gamer because your first game on a console was Call of Duty MW2 and when Sonic got released you were 3 years old so it explains the criticisms of the other useless reviews.

The game itself was a huge revolution and was one of the best Dreamcast games. And as every Sonic game, the camera is annoying, the voice acting and the motion capture are not the best points of it but, does a glitched camera and a bad voice acting ruins the game ? If it was bad acting in GTA I would consider.

Despite that, the game is pretty fun, various missions and mini games are available to extend the time of play though the game is quite short (3 hours to end the main Sonic story, but you have 7 chars stories, each is different and more or less shorter. With that you can do trials, 3 per level with each char + mini games and 60 missions throughout the main maps using all characters).
Finally, a 360 controller is highly recommended, or try to use x360e. But if you can buy this game you can buy a controller.

- This game is definitely one of the best games I ever played in my entire life. I can play it over and over remembering that when I played this game for the first time, I was 11 years old. I'm now 21. :D

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure is a single-player 3D action-platforming game from 10 years ago, and is the first 3D main Sonic game in franchise, not including spin-offs. (Sonic R!) As a result of such major step, it changed Sonic franchise somewhat, from gameplay to style and world. You take control of 6 characters with varying gameplay styles to them, from simply beating the level to, gasp, fishing. It also includes a virtual pet thing (A-Life!) in form of Chao.

Now, since this is old game and most people are familiar with it, let's talk about this Steam port.

First, ports history. First came Sonic Adventure, which was a launch title for a Dreamcast. After few years later GameCube players got to enjoy Sonic Adventure: Directors Cut (SADX) which enchanced the game and added missions mode along with unlockable ports of 8-bit Sonic titles. It was then ported to the PC in 2003 year with almost no change. Now, in the 2010 it got rereleased to Xbox 360 and PS3 downlodable services and later it came to PC once agian, onto Steam, as part of Dreamcast Collection. So, how does 2010 Steam version compares?

Xbox 360 and PS3 release actually worked like original Sonic Adventure (Didn't check if that was like split DX or actual original, sorry), with DLC available that would upgrade it up to DX edition, lacking 8-bit sonic unlockables though. For Steam version, it's already build-in into the game, so once you purchase this game, you get your whole 2010 DX edition. BUT the achievements stayed exclusive to console versions only. Also, analog control seems to be translated to digital controls just fine, though there are one or so spots where you will have to adjuct camera around and crawl slowly so not to fall off.
Main competention there comes with comparison to older 2003 PC edition. From technical standoint, the new game release should work better with new hardware, even though I must say that both of them seemed to work fine on Windows 8. I can't notice it myself, but I read that 2010 port has it running at 60 FPS compared to 2003 one 50 FPS. In Steam edition they tried to keep aspect ratio true to how it looked on Dreamcast/GameCube, and as a you will see it being played in a window that doesn't take up your whole (wide) screen, with remaining parts of it being covered with blue-purple pattern... I think that I like staying true to original, with pattern of frame not trying to catch your eyes with colorful art or anything. If you want game to take up whole widescreen by stretching, go with 2003.
Steam release also has this glitch, due to which your configuration simply will not be saved! To make it save, you will have to go and manually mess with your computer's registry (you can read more in Steam forum of the game). I can guess that Steam doesn't allow games to mess with user's computer registry, since I read that retail copies work just fine. Why does it even need registry to work? ...Well, I can guess that it was mostly based off 2003 PC port, from back when most console ports were weird and had no idea how gaming works on computers.
A little thing, Steam SA has only Player 1 controls working... No, Sonic Adventure is not exactly 2-Player game, but there was little bonus that the second player could control Tails on screen, at Sonic's gameplay. Can't do it anymore.
Even though it's based off older PC port, structure of files seemed to change, meaning that programs that worked for 2003 edition, as well as any mods, will not work on this one.

Oh, and finally, in-game changes compared to older title... Well, it's actually pretty much same. Almost. For there is rather big change - all of unlockable Game Gear Sonic games got cut. Yep, that means that the only reason to collect emblems now is Metal Sonic skin that you get for all of them. If you already played 8-bit Sonic titles or actually own real things, then you may not care about this, but otherwise it heavily points at 2003 version as a better one. Why have they done this, I don't know, since you there are no 8-bit Sonics on Steam on sale. Well, maybe only in some kind of collection on XBox 360 and PS3.
Oh, and Chao. Should be same, but I heard that 2010 version changed something about breeding, that not every color combination is possible. Sure thing transferring chao is not supported in PC versions either. And I don't know how it was on 2003, but very often you will experience polygon flickering in Chao Gardens, biggest offender to me being a wearable Golden Pot object.

Allright, that's all for differences. Now, game by itself...
As a launch game for Dreamcast and it was the first major 3D game of Sonic... That alone meant two things: how rushed it will be and how possibly it may change the face of Sonic (not literally, even if some fans are complaining about green eyes). Now, it did had a lot of changes in a way it worked. Most importanly, physics were simplicifed compared to 2D masterpieces, and as a result it mostly became a game about usual platforming and speed. Loop-de-loops used something what some say as scripted"
date: in that Sonic is "glued" to invinsible path. (And glued badly!). Hell

reviewText:
Has not changed since the original aside from slight graphical updates made every once in a great while to fix some buggy errors. Still gives me headahces like I remember due to wonky camera.

The story is nice and introduces Chaos and chaos. It also introduces Chaos chaos which are really difficult to get (and in SA2 is expanded to 3 different Chaos chao, one for each alignment.)

This game introduced a new character or two along with giving voices to all those who had previously had no voice (save for Sonic and Eggman who would speak on occassion in SEGA Sonic the Hedgehog (arcade game).) It also introduced Homing Attack paths which are usually useful for getting in shortcuts or starting an expert path to the finish.

I still love Tails story due to how broken he is as a character (being able to fly straight to the finish in under one minute in almost all stages aside from Speed Highway) and I still despise Big's story due to how out of place it is along with just being seemingly annoying to me (I love cats, but Big can be a bit annoying at times.) Every other character is alright.

The soundtrack got a dandy new sound to it thanks to Jun Senoue (aka the guy who also created Crush40 :) .) Also, pretty neat that the guy voiced Parappa the Rapper does Knuckle's theme song which is pretty kicking here.

Overall, I don't mind a slight headahce every time I play due to the camera angle, game is bad to polygon ceiling but fun to play every now and then.

reviewText:
One of the best Sonic Games of all time. I played this when the Dreamcast originally was released here in the United Kingdom and was the first game I ever owned for it. I immersed myself within the game immediately, playing it all day, everyday and whenever I could. When I couldn't? I played it in my mind until I could be reunited with it.

Even after all these years, going back to this game has blessed me with the realisation of how enjoyable it was and still is. The game is simple and fast to beat, but everything else a long side the main missions is what makes it a truly epic game. If you truly love playing this game, everything you once knew comes back to you instantly, I don't think there was anything I had forgotten about this game, and there are not many games that give you that experience, proving how enjoyable and entertaining it is.

The soundtrack is the most memorable part of the game and is by far one of the best sound tracks of any game every released in my opinion. If you haven't heard of CRUSH 40 go give them a listen, however I reckon most Sonic fans know who they are and how amazing their work is. Sure there are some bugs here and there that were in the Dreamcast and Gamecube versions but it's a small price for how nostalgic and great this game is and was for it's time.

All characters have good and cross-weaving storylines that inevitably come together at the end to defeat the 'Ultimate Evil', ignorantly created by the infamous Dr.Eggman.

On the side there is cart racing, and the amazing Chao gardens. Chao are little baby creatures that live peacefully with humans and can morph and gain stats in strength, run, flight etc...and can then be put into Chao races. Once you've completed the game and done what you can, you'll probably find yourself here a lot, as the Chao are just literally the best god damn things ever.

If you haven't played Sonic Adventure/SADX, then I suggest you should. It is by far one of the best games of the Sonic Franchise.

reviewText:
This review is not condemning Sonic Adventure as a bad game, it is calling out this port for being terrible. So, please, do not downvote this just because it's a negative review!

Since most people already have their opinions of Sonic Adventure I feel it is unneeded to talk about much of the gameplay and instead will only talk about the port.

The GoodIt's Sonic Adventure on a modern system.
The game's keys are fully rebindable on both keyboard and controller.
The BadThe game seems to pull the textures and controls from the Dreamcast version and not the Gamecube version. (Gamecube is the DX version.)
There is no proper widescreen support, you must always play in 4:3 and if you set it higher the game will still be in 4:3, but will have borders. (The update from awhile ago made it so that the borders are no longer on the top and bottom of the game screen, but they are still on the sides.)
The game's mission mode is currently bugged and you cannot read the mission hints from the mission screen, this means you are required to use an external resource for the missions.
In Tail's airplane minigame the crosshair for the game doesn't scale properly with the screen size so you have to set your resolution lower to be more successful at that minigame.
As stated before the camera controls seem like they're from the Dreamcast version; however, they attempt to include some of the second analouge stick controls from the DX version. This often means you just end up fighting the camera if you attempt to rotate it.
This one might be some personal bias, but it feels like there are more invisible walls in this version than the DX version.
The unlockable Game Gear games, that the Gamecube version had, are removed from this version.
SummaryI advise people to not purchase the Steam version and instead get a copy of Gamecube's Sonic Adventure DX and run it through Dolphin using the options to improve the graphics, this will actually play better than this port.
If you can't pull that off look for the 2003 Sonic Adventure PC port as it is actually a much better port than this! If you cannot find that version here is a guide on how to mod this version to be the older one: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=299808681
I've rewritten this review as of 1/15/2016 to change the formatting into a list, the same general ideas are still there.

reviewText: Sonic Adventure DX, despite its numerous bugs, will always have a place very close to my heart. The joy of zipping through levels as Sonic makes the odd instance of sloppy programming very forgivable.\n\nThat said, I hope that everyone who was involved with programming the game's camera, designing missions 53 & 54, and making Big the Cat's stages goes on a nice skiing holiday to the Alps. To get there, they will take a luxury airplane with a faulty engine. The plane will be filled with crates of rusty chainsaws, kitchen knives, thumb tacks, petrol cans, barbed wire, jars of nitroglycerin, shrapnel, broken glass, hacksaws, junior hacksaws, golf clubs, scissors, lawn mowers, dynamite, rusty nails, staples, hiking gear, leaky batteries, circular saws, poison, hammers, craft knives, power drills, throwing stars, machetes, potato peelers, a mezza luna, syringes, caltrops, garden shears, hedge trimmers, flip knives, and meat cleavers. The pilot will be Helen Keller.

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure DX is a GameCube game that was well recieved by fans but not so much with critics. Why? Let's find out

STORY  Story itself isn't very interesting. You meet misterious echidna called Tikal and well.... er..... i don't really know. But at least it tries to take itself seriously unlike newer sonic games so that's a huge plus!

GAMEPLAY  Every character haves own unique gameplay style. Sonic is get to the goal ring or capsule, Tails is get to the goal ring or capsule before Sonic, Knuckles is collecting pieces of the master emerald, Amy is get the hell away from some robot, Gamma is run'n'gun, and Big is fishing

Sonic  Stages are fast paced and just dang fun to play
Tails  Same like Sonic but preasure is bigger
Knuckles  Not too bad. At least radar shows all 3 pieces at the same time
Amy  Panty Shot Adventure DX. But for real, it's least interesting one. She runs so sssssssllllllloooooooowwwwwww and level design can be a*s sometimes
Gamma  It controls much better and faster than in SA2. It's really fun but time limit is unnecesary
Big  I can't believe i'm saying this but sweet damn...... i enjoyed.......


SOUNDTRACK  It's almost flawless. This is type of music that i want in sonic games. Bit*hing guitar solo, awesome vocals..... not this techno Violin, Piano stuff....


OVERALL  Not as amazing as SA2 but it's still great. Yeah camera and framerate can be a*s sometimes and you will hurt your Chao just by accident more than you think, but it didn't ruin experience for me. It's Dreamcast/GameCube classic that you don't want to miss. 8/10

reviewText:
After having played the Dreamcast, GCN, and finally PC version of this game, I can say that this is pretty decent overall.
It has all the goodies that the Dreamcast didn't, such as the black market, hero/dark chao, and a reward for collecting all 130 emblems (not spoiling it). Of course, it also has the enhanced HD graphics if those are up to your taste (some prefer nostalgia).

Pros:
E-102 Gamma (shooting stages)
Open World (Could be a con for some)
Tails accompanies Sonic in his action stages, and can be controlled by a second player to collect items.
Did I mention Tails isn't in a stupid mech?
Treasure hunting stages are more polished than SA2, and provide a better detection system.
The game feels fluid, and the controls work properly for the most part.
The goals of each stage are clearly explained
Flashy powerups
Excellent menu theme
Chao garden
Hidden emblems that can be found throughout the open world
Intense, action based gameplay (for most stages anyway)

Cons:
Big.
Camera can be wonky (is a problem in all versions)
Screen resolution is somewhat awkward depending on your monitor
Chao cannot be transferred from SADX to SA2 (without the use of mods)
Button to pick up a chao is mapped to the same button that pulverizes it (spin dash)
No online capabilities, so no online bonuses like on the Dreamcast (again, modding may fix this)
Terrible voice acting
Mediocre story
Open world is pretty mundane
No Shadow (I kid...)

Has this game aged well? Probably not, but that doesn't mean it's not fun. It can provide a sense of nostalgia for previous players, and still entertain newcomers. I still prefer the GCN version over this, but this is a solid substitute that can be worth your time.

reviewText: It's fun and will provide quite a bit of playing time, but it does have it's quirks. For ten bucks you get 50 hours of gameplay if you are a completionist, but if you're the type that just plays a game and is done with it then this probably isn't for you. The graphical settings for this game a little bit weird in the way that it favors 16:9 monitors, which I am not a big fan of. Also, if you're going to be buying this game I would recommend having a controller to play with, because playing on a Keyboard and Mouse for these types of games isn't too fun.\n\n(Edit: November 25th, 2015, They seem to have updated the game adding achievements and changing the setup menu. While this doesn't change anything gameplay wise, it makes things a lot easier to configure with more resolutions that are higher than 720p, easier controller setup, and a better UI for changing settings.)

reviewText:
This game has a great storyline in it. If you're a Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Amy Big and E-102 fan. This game allows you to play those characters. I played and finished this game story, 3 times.

However I would like controller support like Sonic Adventure 2 has got. As playing it with the keys on the keyboard is tiring. And my hands would feel more comfortable to play the game at ease with the controller.

reviewText:
I had a good time on this game. Sonic Adventure DX is the 2003 version of Sonic Adventure (1999 on Dreamcast). This game proposes a new you look for almost all the characters, the current look for the Sonic Universe characters. Soundtracks are very good once again, the graphism are colorful without being so childish and the storyline is amazing. However, the gameplay is really hard to explain. You will have to play as the 6 game main characters which you will follow their stories, you have Sonic for Speed acts, Tails for the Race against an opponent , Knuckles for the Treasure Hunting acts, Amy for the Escape acts, Gamma E-102 for the Demoliton Time Trail acts and Big for [Huge drumbeats intensifies]....Fishing acts.
͠° ͟ʖ ͡°

The world is composed of two parts for each characters ; the acts and the open world which you can have acces to the Chao World and hug your tiny adorable Chao you proudly named Ronald Reagan. In this game, you also have a big load of mission and secondary objectives like the fact you can reach every emblem in the game and obtain a very special additional character. The new archivement are OK in terms of difficulty. The game is also not that hard but you could experience some disagreements with the camera.

→ 72/100

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure DX is a classic, and a good one at that. And yes, I said good. Not great, not awesome,  good.  My opinion may be blurred by the nostalgia I feel when I play it, so I'm trying my hardest to base this review on facts.

The story is nice, and has an interesting structure. I also love how the player can choose what levels they do, by walking through areas like Station Square and Emerald Island to get to where they need to go, like you would in an RPG. The gameplay is fun, with 6 characters available, each offering different levels and their own storylines, unlike in SA2 (Sonic Adventure DX) where there are just 3 characters which are ruined versions of the characters in this game, along with their evil counter-parts who do exactly the same as them to make 6 shoddy characters. The soundtrack is awesome although sllightly cheesy, with lyrics making you want to hang yourself. The levels are well-made and fun, especially those where you play as Sonic. And of course, who could forget Chaos, the cute, jolly creatures available to be looked after and raced? Personally, I didn't find them that interesting, but I can see why many love them!

Of course, this game has flaws. And many. First off, the camera angles are atrocious, which should be expected in a fast-paced, 3D game, especially when it comes from SEGA. The game is full of glitches which ruin your fun in multiple ways by causing you to die constantly for no reason. The characters are, like in SA2, extremely cringy and un-funny, with their annoying voices and catchphrases, including their god-awful mouth-syncing. Knuckles' levels are boring and repetitive, although more fair and fun than what they were in SA2.

To conclude, SADX is bad but enjoyable. It's fun levels and gameplay compensate for it's bugginess and how, for a 3D game, it isn't the best. As I mentioned before, I played this as a child and feel a lot of love towards it, so don't take my word for it.

Final verdict: 7/10
TL;DR: A fun game with a great design and soundtrack, although it has many bugs and glitches which create many flaws, along with it's cringy characters.

reviewText:
This is a game I have a history with. As a Kid I loved it. As a Cynical Teen" I believed "It didn't hold up very well when I replayed it because the game isn't as good." Then I just basically decided to shut the heck up and rate it based on how fun it is now and not how it was or how it will be.

Gameplay:
This introduced the 3D gameplay of Sonic so you can expect it to be a bit buggy. And yes. It's a bit buggy sometimes but you know it was Sega's first attempt so you can forgive them slightly. There's 6 characters and they all play differently so i'll be rating their gameplays seperately.

Sonic: He plays just like you'd think he would. He has the spin dash and the jump like in the genesis days
date:
but in this game he got a few new powers. He can home into an enemy by jumping twice (Akin to the Flame Shield in Sonic 3) he also has the light speed dash and attack where he can dash through a set of rings and later enemies.

His stages are action packed get to the End. (also if you replay stages a second person can play as Tails like in Sonic 2/3 ^_^. It doesn't help much but it's a nice touch). Almost perfect gameplay. I'm not saying perfect as there's room to improve.
9/10

Tails: He's like Sonic except he doesn't get the Homing Attack or the Light Speed Dash/Attack
recommended:
but he can fly instead and hit robots with his tails.

Tails' stages are races against Sonic (typically) and you can beat Sonic because there are shortcuts placed that Sonic can't get to. My only gripes with this are.
1. Sonic rubberbands. (meaning the farther you are ahead the faster he goes. he even teleports sometimes.)
2. They are shorter versions of Sonic's stages.

I give it an 8/10

Knuckles: Knuckles plays completley differently. He retains his glide and climb abilties but gains the ability to dig and punch
hoursPlayed:
His gameplay is spent searching for the emerald shards. There are 3 in every level and you have to find them all.
This version of treasure hunting is REALLY fun. (SA2 ruins it a bit).

I give it an 8/10

Amy: Now this is Amy's first time being playable in the main series.(and the last that I know of until Sonic Boom: Rise of Lyric :C poor amy).
She plays differently to the other characters in that she hits enemies with her hammer and runs away from a badnik named Zero the whole time. (No I don't find this "sexist" because Amy actually fuels the plot and her being kidnapped isn't because "Shes a dainty girl" it's because she fuels the plot.)
Amy gets a small amount of stages so it doesn't drag on too long.

I give her a 7/10

E-102 Gamma:
He pl-... HEY GET OUT OF MY PC! "HES A ROBOT ZOMG HE DOESN'T PLAY LIKE SONIC 0/10 SUX"... anyways yes he doesn't play like any other sonic character to date but IT'S NOT BAD! It's a fun gameplay style and it's different. (I'll go over why I love gamma more in the story section) He shoots enemies to gain time because THE TIMER COUNTS DOWN AND NOT UP! And if it gets to 0 you will die. He plays through missions.
I give him an 8/10

Big:
I don't hate Big. I think his gameplay is out of place but I don't hate him. He fishes. Thats all I have to say.

6/10 (for being out of place.)

Gameplay total: 7.5/10

Story:
Each character has a different story but I'll lump a few sets together because they are related.

Sonic/Tails: They have a story about fighting [s]Dr. Robotnik[/s] Dr. Eggman and they usually stay together.

Knuckles: He's usually on his own finding the emerald shards. Dr. Eggman managed to trick him again.

Amy/E-102 Gamma: Not gonna spoil it but they have an interaction that is great.

Big: He's usually on his own fishing and trying to find his frog Froggy but he finds a few other people along the way.

Rating: 8/10 (if Gamma's story wasn't here it would be an 7/10)

Music:
9/10. Just listen to this soundtrack on Youtube.

Final Score:
8/10 - Great Game I recommend it a lot."

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure

Tive o prazer de jogar o original na Dreamcast.

Lançado pela Sega em 1998 e 1999 para o Dreamcast, em 2003, foi lançado Sonic Adventure DX: Director's Cut, para Nintendo GameCube e PC.

Sonic Adventure evolui em todos os aspectos, é o primeiro jogo em 3D da série Sonic
O visual dos personagens mudou bastante, todos ganharam um estilo mais radical, principalmente Sonic que ficou com uma aparência mais radical que o clássico.

Enquanto a História passado alguns anos após Sonic e Knuckles terem derrotado Eggman na Death Egg, a cidade de Station Square é ameaçada por um novo inimigo, Chaos, que se alimenta das esmeraldas do caos, ao alimentar-se das 7 esmeraldas Chaos torna-se Perfect Chaos uma verdadeira ameaça.

O Dr. Eggman, queria controlar Chaos e ajuda-lo na busca das 7 esmeraldas para destruir, Station Square e construir em o seu império Robotnikland ou Eggmaland.

Cabe aos heróis impediram Eggman e recuperarem as esmeraldas antes que seja tarde demais.
É possivel jogar seis Personagens com História diferentes que acabam por interligar-se.

As personagens são : Sonic the Hedgehog, Tails, Knuckles, Amy Rose, Big the Cat e E-102 Gamma.

Temos um mundo aberto para explorar a vontade: Station Square, uma cidade muito movimentada, Mystic Ruins, uma floresta muito extensa e cheia de mistérios. Egg Carrier, a nave de Eggman, vale a pena explorar todos os cantos.

Sonic Adventure possui sérios problemas de câmera, onde perdemos a noção do espaço temos de perder algum tempo a ajustar a câmera manualmente.

Um dos melhores Sonic que algumas vez joguei.

You are ready Sonic Adventure?

Very Good
★★★★

reviewText:
Does this game hold up to it's Dreamcast original?

Yes, but that's not a really good thing.

~Pros
-Multiple  Characters
-Replay Value
-Nostalgic

~Cons
-Terrible Camera
-Can clip through terrain & some enemies
-Bad Story
-Bad Controls
-Bad Voice Acting

STORY

The game's story (or lack of one) is about Sonic arriving in the city of Station Square (which is actually more of a glorified shopping mall) because he's bored & has nothing better to do. Sonic then finds some water monster called Chaos attacking police, intervenes & saves the day. Later while catching some rays by the pool he sees Tails flying a plane & then crashes said plane on the beach but somehow survives uninjured.  Sonic rushes after him & the two group up to go on a journey of finding all the Chaos Emeralds which just so happen to be in the city you're in because why not?

Eggman shows up, farts in your face & steals them from you.  Later you collect more emeralds only to lose them because Knuckles decides to slap you around until you crap them out & Eggman snatches them up.  After all of your blunders you finally find out Eggman wants the emeralds to feed them to Chaos.  His reason for doing so is destroying the city & building a theme park called Robotnik Land" over the ruins because again
date: why not?\n\nSo you go after him in an attempt to stop him from destroying the city.  Along the way you find Amy being abducted by one of Eggman's robots so you go after her & eventually wind up on the Egg Carrier (which is probably the coolest hub in the game).  As you progress through the ship you fight a Robot called E-101 Gamma & just as you're about to destroy the foul creation of evil Amy stops you.  E-101 takes a liking to Amy for some reason & decides to no longer work for Eggman.  Gamma then goes on a journey of saving his Robot Brothers from Eggman's control by murdering them one by one.  Ah
recommended:
brotherly love.

Eventually you fight Chaos & Robotnik a few more times & all is well. Until Chaos destroys the city & gains his final form Perfect Chaos. You then fight him as Super Sonic in one big DBZ style rip off & then the game ends with everyone (except all the dead & homeless survivors) living happily ever after.

Until Sonic Adventure 2.


FEATURES

You play as Sonic
hoursPlayed: Tails
helpfulPercent: Knuckles
votesHelpful: E-101 Gamma
votesTotal: and Big The Cat.  You go through world hubs to get to levels and each level plays pretty terribly.  In the fast segments (Which are supposed to be the highlight of Sonic) you hit walls
votesFunny: can't control yourself very well
commentsCount: and sometimes you'll clip straight through the ground or through walls.\n\nYou unlock the extra characters by playing through Sonic's main story
column16:
and the extra character's levels are just rehashes of the same levels so it's just there to add replay value.  If you complete all the story modes for each character you unlock Super Sonic and fight the final form of Chaos.

There's also a "Missions" menu where you go around the world up fulfilling mundane tasks that were meant to unlock Game Gear games on the GCN but are now reduced to simple Achievement farming since the GG games are not in this version.

GRAPHICS

If you played this on the DC or GCN you're not missing much.  The game is pretty much an exact port
column17: that somehow adds new problems and makes the older issues worse.  The graphics have been improved slightly over it's DC counterpart but are not as good as the GCN version and some areas are glitchy with texture clipping and shadow flicker
column18:
especially in Big's levels.

GAMEPLAY

Gameplay varies for each character that you play.

First thing you'll notice is this game has an overworld hub.  I dunno what they were thinking adding this to the game.  I guess they wanted the "Adventure" in the title to mean something
column19: but the hubs are so small it's really a useless feature that only serves to take up space & add useless text dialog to manequin people walking around town.  In any case
column20: you go to levels through these hubs but you usually have to solve some mundane puzzle first before you can get into each level.\n\nSonic's levels start as simple "run as fast as you can to the end" but later on they turn into slow platforming segments.  There's even one level where all you do is farm rings so you can buy an emerald from a casino.  This level used to have a running segment between all the ring farming but they cut that out for some reason which is kind of lame since that was one of the more fun parts in the game.  Every now and then you'll fight a boss which range from baby-mode easy to down right broken & frustrating.  Egg Viper is the worst boss in any Sonic game (or any game) ever
column21:
imo.

Tails' levels are a similar style to Sonic's except you're racing him to the finish & you have to beat him to progress.  Aside from new shortcuts everything is pretty much the same.

Knuckles' levels are all about finding gem shards of the master emerald.  You go around each level with a Radar that tracks each gem.  Knuckles probably has the best game mode since you actually feel like you're on an "Adventure" & not some linear path.  Sadly
column22: his levels also have some of the worst fixed camera angles in the game.\n\nAmy's Levels are comparable to Tails'
column23:
except you're not racing to the finish but trying to outrun one of Eggman's robots.  Every now and then he'll jump-scare you & try to capture you.  Her levels aren't bad but they are slower compared to other characters.

E-101 Gamma is a robot who shoots things with homing missiles.  His missions are mostly blowing stuff up & reaching the end of the stage.  At the end of each stage you'll fight a miniboss with the last 2 stages being real bosses.  Gamma's storyline is probably the best out of all the characters.

Then there's
column24: ugh. Big The Cat.  Big's levels are the worst in the game.  His pet frog ate a Chaos emerald & is now running away from Eggman's robots so you have to go after him & capture him by fishing.  Yes
column25: they decided to put a fishing mini-game as a requirement for beating a Sonic game.  These levels aren't hard
column26: but if you don't know the trick to catching Froggy they may take you some time.\n\nAfter completing every Story Mission you unlock Super Sonic
column27: which let's you fight Final Chaos in Super Sonic's form.  It's mostly just Run as fast as you can & hit the boss 3 times.  Then the game ends.  Nothing too impressive
column28:
really.

GLITCHES & ISSUES

There are still some parts of the game that I remember being broken on Dreamcast that are still broken in this version.  One of which involves riding a stone snake through a part of the Mayan level but Sonic is constantly fidgeting and clipping through the snake
column29: or when you need to ride an elevator with Amy she will constantly clip through the elevator and drop to her death.  You'd think after almost 20 years they'd fix these glitches.\n\nThe biggest problem this game has is its camera.  It goes everywhere and nowhere.  It clips through walls
column30:
goes behind objects to obstruct your view and has set angles in certain areas that just make the game harder because of the angle it's forced into.

Voice acting is bad but it's not the worst I've heard.  Sounds and music are decent.  The best song in this game is in the title screen.  Every character also has their own theme song which isn't too bad.

This version of DX also doesn't include the Game Gear games that the original Gamecube rendition has which is rather disappointing.

OVERALL

In short
column32: there are bad Sonic games & this one is the latter.  You may want to wait for a sale of some sort before buying unless you really wanna feel some good old Dreamcast nostalgia.  Sadly
column33: if you only played the GCN version you'll just be disappointed."

reviewText: The first 3D Sonic game. Back in 1998, making all new Sonic gameplay, creating a character for Sonic and friends was huge task for Sega, and they've done it very well. One of the best 3D games ever, Sonic has so much freedom in movement, very nice control and precision, probably the best in all Sonic games. Side characters: Tails, Knuckles, Amy, Big and E-102 also quite interesting to play, and they offer different gameplays. The stages are very good, they are non-linear, unlike modern games, and free for discovering some stuff. And the best part of game is EPIC Soundtrack, I think it is the best in all Sonic games. Rock tunes along with techno beats and some folk music makes it so much fun to listen and adds even more fun in playing stages.\nMy score: 9/10. Sega made the first 3D Sonic game really decent. Yes, there are some bugs with camera and clipping walls, but in 1998 it was astonishing success. BTW it is the most selling game on Dreamcast

reviewText:
Synopsis:
This is a very fun game, that will run on almost all modern hardware (if not all). It is pretty cheap here on Steam, and a game worthy to add to your collection. It may have aged a little poorly, and might have some glithes, but is still a very fun time. Heck, I have put 96 hours into this game since I got it back on December 2X, 2013. And don't think I am a nostalgia- blind knuckehead, as I had never played this game before I got it on Steam. Also, the cutscenes don't get too in the way, as there aren't too many of them, and they last an average of 30 seconds. And they are hilarious.

Pros:
+Fun, fast gameplay
+good level design
+Doesn't drag out stages or hub world (perfect size)
+Many fun playable characters
+Hilarious, cheesy cutscenes
+Fast load times
+Price

Cons:
-Poorly aged
-Loose controls at times
-Glitchy (especially with scripted sections)
-Big the Cat isn't very fun to play as
-Camera can be a pain sometimes

Final words:
Buy this game if you love platformers. Now.

reviewText: While the Director's Cut of Sonic Adventure (Or, to use its proper Japanese name, Sonikku no Adobencha) ultimately improves on the original game, it is not without its flaws. For example, Knuckleboy the Enchilada is still plagued by an obscure, yet omnipresent rendering error that causes him to appear red instead of the intended yellow, which severely hampers the game's racial subtext - while he was supposed to represent the Asian continental subconscious, many now incorrectly believe he is the physical manifestation of Native American spiritual beliefs. There are also a lot of translation errors. Some of the more noticeable ones are when Sonikku tells Amy Rose (another mistranslation - her Japanese name actually translates to Horse Horse) about the numerous ghosts haunting his apartment, they use the word ghouls" instead of "ghosts"
date: which may lead the player to believe he is actually besieged by some sort of zombies. This can lead to some confusion down the line when his apartment actually DOES get beset by an undead horde
recommended: as many might believe he was already suffering from that problem
hoursPlayed: when the evolution from ghosts to zombies is supposed to represent him coming to terms with his bisexuality.\n\nHowever
helpfulPercent: this is still an excellent Visual Novel. While the sex scenes could use some better writing and voice acting
votesHelpful: this is still a story that you owe it to yourself to experience."

reviewText: Dont bother with this abysmal port unless you are willing to take the time and effort to download un official tweeks just to make the game play correctly.  How bad is it? you need to manualy create a reg key just to get your configuration files to save. then if you want full wide screen you need to replace the configuration file with one downloaded from the internet. you are then limited to 1440*900 as the only widescreen option no higher no lower. as a consiquence the game looks poor since it has NO advanced graphics settings such as anti alaising standard stuff for over a decade now. it controls okish but the game is just a crummy port plain and simple. I own Sonic adventure  on the Sega Dreamcast,Nintendo Gamecube, Sony PS3 and windows based steam. The PS3 port all though not great is far better. for the best experience dust of a Dreamcast or gamecube skip this flaming pile of dung if at all possible.

reviewText: Sonic Adventure was a major milestone for the Sonic The Hedgehog series as the first fully 3D game in the franchise realesed for the Sega Dreamcast on September 9th 1999 as a launch title for segas last console it became one of the best games in the series getting a enhanced port for the gamecube in 2003 after sega became a third party company this game has many playable charecters many levels and objectives a amazing soundtrack and overall a good story though the game does look dated now a days it has aged extremly well and one game I enjoy dearly though to be honest the steam port is not the best port of this game. Simmilar to the PS3 and XBOX 360 ports it has a purple boarder around the screen not making it full screen which dosen't seem that big of a deal but it can get annoying which is why I think the gamecube port is the best way to play this game it in full screen and has the enhanced graphics and addons as the steam,PS3 and XBOX ports yet if your looking for a cheap and fun way too get your sonic fix than i suggest giving the steam port at least a try

reviewText:
An excellent game back in the 90s and even now i still consider it one of the best Sonic games and my personal favorite 3D Sonic game. Sonic Adventure DX is the remake of Dreamcast's launch title Sonic Adventure and it's still considered the very best of Sonic's 3D carrier and for very good reasons.
The game actually haves a complicated story though not as good as Sonic Adventure 2's story (That game's story was fantastic). Instead of the classic old school saving the forest and the animals from an evil dictator" this game actually haves Sonic interacting with humans for the first time and the story involves a lethal water-like creature possessed by Dr.Eggman called "Chaos" the only guy who can stop Chaos' rampage is the one and only Sonic The Hedgehog but this time he's not alone.
In this story every Sonic character takes the spot from the little flying fox Tails to the super strong Echidna Knuckles and even the little pink hedgehog Amy Rose from Sonic CD makes a return this time with a very different make up and also two new comers E-102 Gamma and Big the Cat.
The gameplay is basically (with the exception of Amy
date: Gamma and Big) the classic team's transition to 3D and because of that the characters have their old abilities only with new power ups and new skills like the homing attack and the light-speed dash\nThe controls are the best in any 3D game
recommended: the characters control just like they should and it's very helpful because this game is everything but linear as the hubs and levels are very big and while it's still "go from point A to point B" you never have to take a specific path because there are a lot of shortcuts.\nThe music is awesome and i'm my opinion one of the best of Sonic
hoursPlayed: the themes
helpfulPercent: the levels and don't forget about "Open your Heart" which was very well composed.\nUnfortunately the game has problems like the voice acting and the cutscenes and the DX version includes tons of glitches that ironically weren't in the original version.\nOverall it's a great game and the DX version includes various extras like Mission mode
votesHelpful: Metal Sonic and the Game Gear games (only in the original PC version and the GC) i suggest to give it a try.\n9/10"

reviewText: I think as far as Sonic in 3D goes, the first Sonic Adventure got a lot of things right that games after it failed to grasp -- yes, even in the presence of 4 fishing stages. If you've come to think of Sonic in 3D as running quikcly across narrow paths crossing the abyss, you should at least go back over this game. Levels in this game have more variety in their structure, such as Ice Cap's  death-pit-free climb through a circular cave, or the almost Mario 64-like ascent up the Pleasure Castle of Twinkle Park. Part of the reason the levels work as well as they do is that every character has a slightly different way to play. For example: Knuckles' stages are all more open-ended and tend toward larger open spaces, while Tails' stages tend to be more straightforward runs of the faster segments' in Sonic's game. While people who are fans of Sonic mainly from Sonic 3 [& Knuckles] might find these changes in gameplay disappointing, I think they help keep the levels fresh. Since Sonic himself goes through nearly every stage and area on his own (including most of the open areas of Knuckles' game!), it makes completionism a bit less of a grind (although the less said about Big's missions, the better).\n\nThat all said, the camera is pretty bad, even now -- and it's probably the reason that the 3D Sonic games after this one tended toward less ambitious level design. This last playthrough I noticed an astounding amount of clipping; I assume this is an issue with the updated version, since while previous versions of the game (i.e., the Dreamcast or 2004 PC versions) didn't have this issue. This is still probably the definitive version of the game. Most of the important graphical effects are here, it runs at a stable 60 FPS on a modern gaming laptop, switching focus doesn't kill the game, and it can run at high-definition resolutions (in a forced 4:3 ratio, admittedly -- but the previous PC release only supported widescreen by cutting off the top and bottom of the screen). The game was rushed a bit to get it out in 1998 before Christmas so the Dreamcast had a killer app, and all versions of the game since (including the bugfixed Dreamcast releases put out for other regions, called the International Edition" in Japan) have struggled to get a stable game out of it
date: and even in this recently-patched version many well-documented bugs are still hanging around. On the other hand
recommended: it's still probably a more stable game than Donkey Kong 64 -- and supports a wider variety of play interests than "wander around a big map collecting stuff".\n\nAnother minor frustration is the lack of cutscenes. While for Sonic's story that doesn't matter much (Sonic's story is defined mostly by the characters around him and he doesn't really develop as a character during it)
hoursPlayed: the other characters all get to be a bit more complex and actually develop as indivduals over the course of the game. Gamma's quest of self-awareness
helpfulPercent: has a surprisingly tragic end to it for a game about a fast talking blue hedgehog; it's not on the level of a game like Super Mario Galaxy
votesHelpful: but it definitely had a lot of thought and heart put into it.\n\nThat's basically my summary of the game -- an ambitious but flawed game that definitely had heart in it
votesTotal: before sequel fatigue and shrinking budgets caused the level design to be formulaic and a bit on the bland side. If I were to recommend a 3D Sonic game other than Generations
votesFunny: this would be it.\n\nYou'd still do well to check out the Dreamcast release
column16: as a few flashy graphical effects courtesy of the console's hardware shading never made it into any of the ports -- Sky Deck in particular has far more dramatic and foreboding lighting and shadows
column17: looking a bit dead in comparison in the DX version. A shame
column18: but these effects are rarely enough to spoil the game; the stable framerate and generally much nicer-looking textures more than make up for it most of the time. (And I suppose a patch to get the proper graphical effect in Sky Deck is not out of the question.)"

reviewText:
This is a...retro game? No this game is cutting edge. Retro Sonic games are from my childhood like Sonic the hedgehog 1 and 2.

I turn around one day and what have I found? My favorite new Sonic video game has grown old. Its graphics are obsolete, outdated, what I so fondly recall as mind-blowing has been reduced to primative, crude countable polygons.

The music though, that takes me back more than any other aspect. As crisp as the very first day those stellar notes flooded out of my CRT and fueled the endless imagination of my young, impressionable mind. The voices, the movement, the environments, the characer interactions, all brand new, every second more amazing than the last.

Not content in having robbed us of the best character in his prime, the cast of VA's suffered a similar blow in the loss of the esteemed Deem Bristow; your talents will be missed but your contributions never forgotten.

reviewText:
I've been a Sonic fan for some time now, and of all the Adventures he has had over the years, this is a close favorite of mine. This is my favorite game of all time. It does have a few flaws, and this PC port is not my favorite though. I prefer the Dreamcast version.
Pros-
6 stories
11 levels with different areas for different characters - These are very nicely designed
Nice variety in gameplay with different characters
Awesome final boss
The Chao Garden - This is the only part of it I prefer over the original DC version. It's done better. That said, I still have spent more time on the Dreamcast chao garden due to the VMU minigame and the fact I play it more.
Cons-
It's missing the charm of the Dreamcast version for me completely.
I only would replay Sonic, Gamma or maybe Tails' stages once I beat mission A
Shinier models - This is my opinion, but I think they look worse
The camera sucks on levels that aren't open-ended
Perhaps glitchier than the Dreamcast version
All but one of the levels are played in Sonic's story, so they can be boring after a few plays in the other character stories (The one he doesn't play is Hot Shelter)
Super Sonic isn't availible in the normal stages even after you've beaten Perfect Chaos

In conclusion, I think the positives in this game far outweigh the negatives as most flaws are minor complaints.
This is a true Adventure, but I recommend beating the Super Sonic story and then playing the game again before giving it a review. Some things might confuse you the first go-round. If you don't want to mod your game than you should really choose another version of this. I recommend the Dreamcast or even Gamecube over this and the X360/PS3 ports, but if a PC is all you have then get it.
Seriously though, get yourself a version of this one way or another. It deserves to be played.

reviewText:
If for some reason you're reading this and not playing the game, let me tell you the pros and cons of buying this game.

Each character has their own style of gameplay centered around their abilities. Sonic, for example, will play differently than Knuckles or Amy.

The Good:

-This is the first appearance of Chao, and if you know anything about Chao, then you get why this is good. for those who don't know, Chao are raisable creatures who take on parts of animals given to them, and inherit stats from animals, birds will help your creation fly, while things like cheetahs will make them faster. All of this to win specific races.

-The levels, minus Big's and E-102's are built fairly well, and feel like they belong in a platforming game. Sonic's feel like a traditional Sonic game (for the most part) while other character's stages fit them just fine.

-Power ups are scattered around the main worlds, and while some are essential, like the light speed shoes, some just help make things easier, such as the crystal ring.

-This game proves that hub worlds can be used in a good way, with the environments being interesting, and having hidden special chao eggs to find, and secrets, such as power ups to gather.

Now For The Bad Things:

-Big the cat. Just...His gameplay is so bad it's basically a joke now.

-The story can be kind of hard to follow if you're trying to keep track of what is happening when, especially when characters split up.

-The EGG VIPER is cheap, and pretty glitchy, at least from my attempts. You'll fall through the floor when dodging that final attack, and not make it back to the platform if you spindash jump into the robot.

-Who thought the two Sky Chase acts were a good idea?

That's all, I'm going to leave the final decision to you, with all that I said, it's up to you if you wanna buy it or not.

I love this game, always have and always will, would recommend to anyone and everyone.

reviewText:
Pure nostalgia right here

I played this game to absolute DEATH back when I had a Dreamcast many years ago, and I still think this is easily one of the best Sonic games. But that just may be me basking in nostalgia. Unfortunately, this game hasn't aged all that well.

Story The story is nothing really to write home about but here I am. A god of destruction, aptly named Chaos" is getting it's hands on the Chaos emeralds
date: turning him into a more powerful creature
recommended: with the help off Eggman of course. And it's up to you as the player to stop him! Pretty straight forward\n\nGameplay Let's start off with the gameplay itself. It's your original Sonic game but remade onto a 3D plane
hoursPlayed:
granted this already has been done before but this time SEGA acutally got it right. You get to enjoy the game not only from Sonic's perspective but from the perspective from other charaters such as Tails and Knuckles. Their stories are different obviously and occasionally do cross with one another. Even if you DO get sick from just "GOTTA GO FAST" then you can enjoy gameplay with Knuckles where you get to the monotonous chore of searching for Emeral shards in various levels that you visited as Sonic or run from a robt who's trying to capture you as Amy. Each character provides a lot of variety to this old game.


Graphics The Graphics...are well...dated. But what can you expect from a game that as originally designed for the dreamcast so everything kinda looks like stretched lego figurines. The animation is alright
voteText: facial expressions can get pretty spooky at times where the character would should a face of shock and it would be a step by step revealing of their face contorting to show the emotion.\n\nLevels The levels are still just as enjoyable and varied for an old game. You've got one level where you running along a beach to save Tails and the next you're in a Casino trying to collect rings to build a high enough pile to get a Chaos emerald. Each level makes you feel like you're playing MORE than just a Sonic game. And to top it all off
helpfulPercent: you have a Hub world where you can run around and talk to other citizens that really have nothing to contribute to the game than just to breathe life into the world. As you run around like the rainbow colored animal you are
votesHelpful: you can find permanent powerups that will assist you in the levels.\n\nIn the end
votesTotal: I recommend giving this game a try if you've never played but yet want to see where Sonic really hit home in a 3D game. Or you just want to relive some nostalgia from the good ol days when Sega wasn't continually destroying itself with each game they release"

reviewText:
If for some reason you're reading this and not playing the game, let me tell you the pros and cons of buying this game.

Each character has their own style of gameplay centered around their abilities. Sonic, for example, will play differently than Knuckles or Amy.

The Good:

-This is the first appearance of Chao, and if you know anything about Chao, then you get why this is good. for those who don't know, Chao are raisable creatures who take on parts of animals given to them, and inherit stats from animals, birds will help your creation fly, while things like cheetahs will make them faster. All of this to win specific races.

-The levels, minus Big's and E-102's are built fairly well, and feel like they belong in a platforming game. Sonic's feel like a traditional Sonic game (for the most part) while other character's stages fit them just fine.

-Power ups are scattered around the main worlds, and while some are essential, like the light speed shoes, some just help make things easier, such as the crystal ring.

-This game proves that hub worlds can be used in a good way, with the environments being interesting, and having hidden special chao eggs to find, and secrets, such as power ups to gather.

Now For The Bad Things:

-Big the cat. Just...His gameplay is so bad it's basically a joke now.

-The story can be kind of hard to follow if you're trying to keep track of what is happening when, especially when characters split up.

-The EGG VIPER is cheap, and pretty glitchy, at least from my attempts. You'll fall through the floor when dodging that final attack, and not make it back to the platform if you spindash jump into the robot.

-Who thought the two Sky Chase acts were a good idea?

That's all, I'm going to leave the final decision to you, with all that I said, it's up to you if you wanna buy it or not.

reviewText:
I've played this game to completion three seperate times, on three different platforms: Dreamcast, Xbox 360, and now PC. I would be lying if I didn't say the Dreamcast felt like the best of them all, but that could just be sign of the times when compared to its contemporaries.

You'll pull your hair out because of the camera, you'll feel lost the majority of the time, and you won't understand half of the action on the screen its going so fast. But there has to be a reason I've put so much time into this game, right? I'm no big Sonic fan, and I could write a list of this game's flaws, and yet there's something about the sense of adventure and the almost automotous speed at which some of the levels whiz by... And a big favourite of mine: seeing the same events from multiple different perspectives, almost like time travel, with each a small story on its own right.

Make no mistake, you will likely ragequit many times, but its flaws (like Big the Cat) are matched by the sheer rawness of this game, close to the likes of Mario 64.

reviewText:
Well I think this game could of done better, but overall this game is good. Originally this was remastered for the Nintendo GameCube as the original was made for the DreamCast around 1999. Saddly the DreamCast got slayed by failing to compete against the PlayStation 2 and ended Sega's console hardware.

Nintendo had been granted to remaster this game as well had some cool Game Gear mini-games, enhanced models and more. Plus the bonus with the GameCube version was linking Chao Garden with the Game Boy Advance.

Saddly this Steam version does NOT come with Tiny Chao Garden support nor have those Game Gear mini-games. Both the PC and GameCube versions failed to enhance this game further that could of been applied: such as the E-102 geometry, movement and gravity that appears awkward to control. And some of the control and camera bug glitches still remained on this Steam version.

So if you are Sonic fan and like to see how Sonic made his first Debut for the Modern Generation, buy it! But if you are fussy short-tempered gamer, otherwise no.

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure DX is a game by SEGA which was offically released on the SEGA Dreamcast as Sonic Adventure in 1999, it was one of the first Sonic games to be in 3D and is the first time for Sonic to appear in his Teenager form.
There are 6 playable characters in this game, Sonic the Hedgehog, Miles 'Tails' Prower, Knuckles the Echidna, Amy Rose, Big the Cat and E-102 Gamma, each with thier own gameplay.

Story:
*NO SPOILERS*

Sonic: It starts as Sonic was in Station Square until he saw a bunch of Police Cars driving past him, Sonic decides to find out what's wrong, then he finds a creature named Chaos, eventually Sonic and Chaos fight until Chaos escapes, the next day Sonic finds out Dr. Eggman (AKA Dr. Robotnick) is looking for the 7 Chaos Emeralds to evolve Chaos into a fearsome beast and destroy Station Square.

Tails: The story for Tails is same as Sonic, he will assist Sonic and help him get the Chaos Emeralds, there is not really a big diffrence in the story except when they got Split up.

Knuckles: Knuckles is the protecter of the Master Emerald which is located in Angel Island, the Master Emerald is a huge emerald that controls all Chaos Emeralds, One day Knuckles was normally protecting the Master Emerald until Chaos appears and shatters it into pieces that flew away in farther locations, Angel Island starts falling and it's up to Knuckles to find the pieces of the Master Emerald and restore it back to it's original form.

Amy: One day Amy was returning from shopping until a bird who escaped from Dr. Eggman bumps into her, Amy decides to help and protect the bird but one of Eggman's robots called Zero is chasing after them, Amy later discovers that the bird's family is missing and Amy decides to look for them.

Big: Big and his friend Frog (named Froggy) were sleeping one day, until Froggy woke up and and found a small weird puddle of water that jumped into Froggy's mouth, it was Chaos' tail, Froggy eventually gets Chaos' tail, swallows Big's Chaos Emerald and escapes to find Chaos, Big hurries to follow him.

E-102G: E-102 (Code name: Gamma) is created by Dr. Eggman and is told to do a practice test of shooting Sonic, Tails and Knuckles dolls, Eggman decieds to let him go against his older brother E-101 Beta to see who is stronger, further in the story E-102G is revealed to be a good robot and decides to help Amy, destroy other E series robots and rescuing the animals inside them.

Gameplay:
As I mentioned earlier, each characters has diffrent gameplay.

Sonic stages are all fast paced and having to reach the goal.

Tails stages are similar to Sonic, except it's racing Sonic to the goal, Shourtcuts are available to win easily.

Knuckles stages are about to find the missing pieces of the Master Emerald, in each stage there are 3 pieces, you will have a radar which will blink when a piece is nearby.

Amy stages are about running away from Zero the robot and escape on a balloon.

Big stages are about fishing Froggy from the water.

E-102G stages are about shooting robots in order to have more time to reach the goal, however the goal is to defeat other E series robots.

Looks/Soundtrack:
The game's graphics was improved when it was re-released as DX, everything looks clear enough and the characters look much better, the soundtrack is still the same but very memorable, especially the character's theme song, you can listen to them in the Sound test section of this game.

Length:
You can finish Sonic, Tails and Knuckles story in 1 hour for each, but the rest will take about 30 mins each, however you still have a total of 130 emblems to collect and a Chao garden where you raise your own Chao, depending on your experience in Sonic games, you can finish it in about 20 hours, but if you are not that good the average time should be 30 hours.
On top of that there are 2 other objectives for each stage for all characters, they can range from collecting certain amount of rings, reaching the goal under the time limit or in other words a harder objective.

Bonus:
According to the DX version there are missions to complete for each character.
*SPOILERS ALERT*
Once you finish the story for all characters you will unlock Super Sonic story, but it is just the Final Boss in where you play as Super Sonic.
Once you collect all 130 emblems, go to trail mode and you can now play as Metal Sonic, however the character feels very similar Sonic but is still a good suprise.
*SPOILER ENDS HERE*

reviewText:
This game is not the best by any means, but fun.
What I mean is the camera is terrible, there is clipping everywhere (especially in Emerald Coast and Windy Valley) and the controls could be much better.
However, this game can be very fun. I have not unlocked every character (yes, I just wanted to write this quickly), but from what I've played, here's what I think:

Sonic: Mostly fun stages, but the stages are BROKEN, by far the worst I've played. You cannot deny they are fun though, and fast.
Tails: Parts of sonic's stages with shortcuts. You race him. Fun, and the stages are less broken too!
Knuckles: Mah Favourite! Gliding is satisfying, however the camera while climbing is atrocious! Other than that, I like hunting for emerald shards.
Big: KILLITWITHFIRE!!! It's been said before and I'll say it again, Big's stages are boring.

Overall, the game has not aged well, however, it is fun...mostly...

reviewText:
SONIC ADVENTURES AREAS Sonic Adventure is what it looks and sounds like, a 3D sonic game with adventure.

PROS
Amazing music; a given for sonic games.
Plays like it should; It plays like a sonic game, which is what you payed $8 for.
Chao Garden; Just.. chao garden
MULTIPLE CHARACTERS; More adventures, each with unique crap.
Lack of Glitches; while some say they experience glitches, I didn't experience much.
Played really smooth; Didn't play suppper slow. Great for Sonic, a series about going fast. Cons
HORRID camera; The camera will occasionally (Actually USUALLY) screw up.

In conclusion, Sonic Adventure is a amazing sonic game. It was sonics step into 3D. It may not look like anything good, but if you play it, it's amazing. As I mentioned before, great music, played smooth, however the camera is terrible.
So just buy this, if you can get past the camera issues

reviewText: So I bet nobody expected this review from me but here we go. Sonic Adventure is surprisingly one of my favourite Sonic games may I say even as good if not way better than Adventure 2 and dare I say some of the 2D games aswell. This game was revolutionary for it's time (1998 in Japan) and here in the States when the Dreamcast launched in 1999. It may not have aged as well as some may like but for an early 3D game" the graphics
recommended:
design and gameplay overall were completely fine. The transition from 2D to 3D may have not been as well received as some might've hoped but it really is hard to come off the success of Sonic 3 & Knuckles.
The models are really except the mouth movements are.....jarring to say the least. The music is overall nice especially the non lyrical songs but soem of those are catchy at least fitting even but a very "in it's time period" kind of thing. The story while pretty generic is interesting is some aspects and each of the 6 characters will have their slight alterations of the story and dialogue dependant on that specific character which adds a bit of flavor to it that Adventure 2 lacks and these 6 characters stories all intertwine at some point(s) too. Despite the human world setting alot of aspects of the game keep true and reference the classics for those of you who like that because sadly after this point I feel that Sonic lost it's way with that with trying to hard to fit into the new millennium and being "edgy".

Now each of the 6 characters have different gameplay styles not gonna lie Sonic's IS the best but I expect nothing less from the gameplay of the title character. Sonic runs and jumps like you all rememeber from the older games along with new abilities too. His levels are also the best too which is good as his story is obviously the longest but the most straightforward trying to find and keep the chaos emeralds from Eggman. Tails plays similar to Sonic but can fly and hover in short bursts with his own little set of new moves. Tails levels revolve around races or timers so think of it like Sonic stages on a timer but he can also visit specific parts of the stages that Sonic cannot so not much to complain here for Sonic and Tails gameplay.

Knuckles gameplay is basically finding pieces of the master emerald the locations are switched up each time you visit the stage but you are given a radar which keeps track of where the 3 pieces are in the stage. Unlike Sonic Adventure 2 you can use the radar to track each of the pieces all at once instead of one at a time. Some of Knuckles sections are vastly different due to the hunting nature of his gameplay along with his climbing ability he has from the games prior he also comes with his new abilities too. His gameplay is a nice change of pace from the other gameplay styles and doesn't bog down the game. Amy is a slower moving character who uses her unique hammer abilities to attack and jump to higher places. Her levels mainly focus on running away from a robot trying to capture her it's different from what we usually see in this series and while she isn't really important in the overall story besides Gamma's section really it's not a bad thing and I somewhat like her section the biggest downfall for her portion is I feel they could've done more with her "puzzle" sections or the sections where you gotta figure something out. Like more of the color cube sectinos or something alike it would've been nice.

Let's get the worst part out of the way and that is Big the Cat while being voiced by John St Jon is a plus he has no importance on the plot except a minor detail involving his friend froggy. His gameplay revolves around fishing which isn't a bad thing per-say but in a Sonic the Hedgehog game? No just no. Luckily his 4 stages can be completed in like a minute each so his portion is the shortest he gets a few abilities/upgrades too surprisingly but yeah there you go we got fishing in a Sonic game. Lastly we have E102 Gamma which plays out similarly to other characters as far as stage design goes he is a bit slower and uses his gun to shoot down enemies and obsticles in his path. Very interesting gamepaly even if you wouldn't expect it in a Sonic game it is pretty fun and he has the best story in the game honestly and really gets into detail and the perspective of one of the tiny animals trapped in a robot which animals being stuck in the enemies has always been a staple for this series so it was nice seeing how Gamma's story played out as he went around "saving" his friends. Then after you beat all of these characters stories you will unlock a secret I mean we all know what at this point but for the sake of this review i'll leave the final portion of this game a surprise. Did I forget to mention you can play each character at your own pace? That is alot better than the forced playstyle and narrative's on the sequel. It's also nice that this adventure actually feels like an adventure with hubs to explore and find stuff and fun little mini games here and there to play.

All in all the game may not have aged well in it's 15+ years of release and it may very well not be a "great" Sonic game or game in general but it's a game that while some small portions may be lackluster the overall experience is a fun ride and well worth checking out for one of the last good Sonic games (not counting handheld titles) even if the PC version has some glitches here and there."

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure DX review

The Good: Very, very, very, much.
The Bad: Try to find

Well, well, we all know what happened to this fellow. It looked like the start of something new for Sega and Sonic after a shocking past, with Sonic Adventure garnering positive reviews and Dreamcast sale’s making a promising start. The cancellation of Sonic X-Treme and the subsequent death of the Saturn looked firmly behind them. Alas, it was not to be. The Dreamcast lasted less than two years as competition had greater developer support, and the release of Sonic Adventure DX in 2003 failed to stand the test of time in comparison to contemporary platform games. Yet few would have predicted many more years of mediocre releases, and I wanted to see what was wrong when a hedgehog that defined my childhood went 3D.

Sonic Adventure plot sees a fight over the possession of the Chaos Emeralds. Dr Robotnil, um, Eggman, in his quest for world domination, gets his flying fortress up and running and seeks the water-based God of destruction Chaos, after destroying the Master Emerald and attempts to exploit his power by finding the Chaos Emeralds. The events spark the interests of six playable characters in the game: Sonic and Tails aim to prevent Dr Eggman from getting his way while Knuckles the Echidna attempts to restore the Master Emerald he was protecting by finding the lost shards. Eggman’s secretly compassionate sidekick E-102 actually wants to free all his fellow robots from his control, Sonic’s girlfriend Amy tries to find her bird friend and Big the Cat keeps losing his frog companion, who has swallowed his lucky yellow Chaos Emerald.

Although the excess of game characters has been one of many problems associated with the Sonic franchise, most of the other characters play quite well. Plenty of crossovers of other characters occur in the plot. Sonic, Tails, Knuckles and Amy host fast-paced levels, with a few differences. Tails can fly, Knuckles has the ability to glide and Amy has a Piko Piko hammer. E-102 takes a slower pace, sporting a few levels to wade through and blast everything with a laser gun while Big the Cat is obsessed with finding his frog companion and whose levels are extremely dull.

Sonic Adventure was so well received at the time because everyone wanted the new Sonic game to be good, and also the graphical quality was unprecedented. Rolling onto the first level, Emerald Coast, it’s easy to see how it was impressive. To see spinning rings, trampolines, item boxes and Sonic’s signature spin dash dazzling in 3D certainly had me amazed at 9 years of age. Seeing Sonic running clear of a killer whale destroying a peer was the icing on the cake. It’s still a decent enough level, with the sun shining on the beach, lots of jumping around albeit occasionally hard to land. It’s a good first impression all round.

After the first level the game’s biggest flaw emerges; relying on Adventure hub fields to find action stages. They serve no purpose other than to advance the plot and to get lost, and are littered with pointless NPC’s. There are a few of these: Station Square, Mystic Ruins and Angel Island; finding the odd clue from an orb to indicate where to be next. The plot is uninteresting thanks to appalling acting as well. Expression is limited, dialogue is sporadic rather than free-flowing and lip-synching is non-existent. There wouldn’t be anything wrong with a plot if it was acted well and didn’t need hub stages but the explorative elements shoehorn the game into something it is not, and should not be. Hub levels in the likes of Spyro the Dragon and Super Mario 64 suited the games spirit of exploring and collecting things. This does not work where core levels are fast and linear, A-B progression.

The core levels don’t get everything right either, being tricky for the wrong reasons. Irrefutably shoddy camera work, questionable design decisions and improperly assigned collision detection lead to deaths because of a design flaw rather than a flaw in the player’s skill. Sonic Adventure is actually quite a good game when thing’s work, demonstrating how Sonic could actually work in 3D. However, too many surrounding factors puncture a decent gameplay mechanic not only by level organisation but carelessness. This game is average not because it’s consistently ordinary, rather an aggregate of many good and many bad moments.

The flaws make you wonder about exploring the depths this game offers. Sonic Adventure allows you to train your own Chao creature, with the part reserved for the Dreamcast’s Visual Memory Unit ported over, almost like a virtual pet mini-game. His stats can be raised to improve his performance in races, and special Chao eggs can be found in the game. This PC DX version also features many additional unlockables such as a mission mode (which unlocks even more), hidden characters and the entire backlog of Sonic games on the Game Gear (although not on the Steam version). Missions are rather mundane though, such as collecting flags or transporting a man to the train station. A lot of the Game Gear games were initially poor and have aged badly also, and look nasty at a PC resolution. If you don’t want to get arrested for downloading and playing these Game Gear games on an alternate emulator, then this remains the only legal way to play these on the PC. But what I want to know is why the time taken to implement these needless extras wasn’t used to fix the game’s bugs?

It’s been an interesting insight into Sonic’s demise: a lack of polish in levels, badly acted plotlines and unnecessary adventure fields between core levels. Despite camera flaws action stages are generally good; levels remain fast, boss battles are challenging but fun and the linear formula has been converted rather well to three dimensions. Many aspects of the famed 2D gameplay are intact: collecting rings, busting badniks and avoiding spikes and traps. The graphics, although dated, are classic Sega-style bright and breezy, as is the somewhat cheesy soundtrack. It’s just a shame this was the start of a decade of rot for Sonic. This was certainly one of his better games in the decade and has enough good points for a Sonic fan to enjoy if you can ride out and ignore the dross, but others should take caution. A loop-de-loop experience of its own, at least it’s good to see Sonic’s showing positive signs of progress recently. 2010’s Sonic Colours scored well and the upcoming Sonic Generations looks very promising. Ignore the trolls, Sonic. I always had faith in you.
