reviewText:
Sonic Adventure is a fairly overrated game. For those of you who haven't already clicked away or tuned out from this review, I assume you'll want to hear me out. Just so no one gets me wrong, I like this game. There are a lot of cool things about it. And I even think it has aged alright.

Sonic Adventure brings the Sonic universe into 3D with five different playable characters, each with their own adventure. There's some good variety. Sonic has the most levels and has the most freedom, as he can go as fast or slow as he wants in most of the levels. Not too much pressure, but lots of possibilities. He's also the most useful character in terms of his abilities. Tails' campaign focuses more on flying through rings and beating Sonic to the end of the levels. So basically, like races or time trials. Knuckles is looking for shards of the master emerald, which has him searching around levels freely rather than in a linear fashion. I really like this campagn because it lets you really appreciate the level design. Amy is running for her life in her stages, being pursued by Eggman's robots. It's a tense run to the finish. Big the Cat has the most unique campaign by far, consisting of a bunch of fishing levels. As much as people hate the character and his levels, I think they're a nice change up and a break from the action while still being somewhat involved as far as gameplay goes. And lastly, Gamma's levels are scrambling to get as much time as possible by locking on to targets. So there's a lot of variety as each character controls in their own unique way.

It's also cool how, even though this was more or less Sega's answer to Super Mario 64, it feels like quite a different type of game. Everyone's stories intertwine at some point and every character gets boss fights, even Big the Cat suprisingly enough. There's replay value for those of you who want to try and get all the medals, and that probably isn't easy but I didn't put myself through that so I can't say for sure. The music is cool, blening band songs with game music. The visuals are also pretty neat. Lots of cutscenes where were nice for the time. Honestly, I really do have fun with this game.

Well if I like all this stuff about it... why am I calling it overrated? Because I hear how GREAT this game is, most likely by people who played it on the Dreamcast when they were kids. The game isn't great by any stretch, but it IS good. I have plenty of complaints. I know it's the director's cut but... there are too many cutscenes in this game. They aren't anything spectacular and don't add a whole lot to the game so having so many pads the playtime and breaks up the action a lot. This is also coupled with the issue that the open world aspects, as they're called, are merely just you running around mostly baren hub worlds with very little to do in them. There are some people to talk to but they are largely unintersting. There are a few things to find and a few places you can go, but most of the overworld is rather pointless. So, basically you have three sections of the game. Cutscenes, hub worlds, and actual levels. The actual levels only make up about a third of your playtme. That's a bit annoying and since going through the overworld and watching these cutscenes happen between pretty much every level... well... it kind of ruins the flow of the game. And Sonic games are kind of about flow. Speed, flow, rhythm. This is counter intuitive to what Sonic games are about.

While characters all control in their own way and have their own missions, they tend to share the same levels. I guess it makes some sense and works in some cases. It'd be tough to win the races as Tails if you never played the levels before as Sonic. Exploring the levels in depth with Knuckles lets you appreciate stuff you may have sped through before. I guess even playing as Big is different since you are fishing and therefore looking for water more than anything else. But Amy and Gamma, on top of having such short campaigns, just play the same levels as other characters. It feels a little lazy after a while and having some new levels along with replaying other ones would've been a good idea. And speaking of Gamma... boy did I hate his campaign. Yeah, I actually thought it was WORSE than Big's. Why? Well, you see, Gamma is the last character in the spinning wheel. I completed the campaigns in that order. So by the time I got to Gamma... his playstyle was a step backwards and largely out of place. He's not all that fast, can't jump very well, and hit attack is locking on to multiple enemies with homing rockets. It's just way too easy compared to the rest of the game... boring even. It feels like it should be one of the first things you do, not the last.

The Chao garden... no I didn't forget. A lot of people love it. I'm sure it's a lot cooler if you had the Dreamcast or GameCube version because... well... you could do stuff with your chao on portable devices. But with this version, you're stuck training them the hard way... the long, tedious way. I just didn't enjoy it. It was boring for me. This isn't what I signed up for when I was looking to play a 3D platformer. It just seemed like there were more important things to do. You know... stop Eggman, get the shards of the master emerald... fish for my froggy friend. ANYTHING but feeding and petting my chao so that I can put it into races and cheer from the sidelines with seems to have little to no effect on the outcome whatsoever. It's all just an overblown and underdeveloped mini game that I have no patience for nor interest in.

So there you have it. It's not a bad game, it's just nowhere near great. I like it, but it has a lot of flaws. Also, this version doesn't sound like the best because of chao garden situation, and the GameCube version has extra games on it as well. This has achievements... I guess... and some capability for modding... but... it's really nothing all that special. I guess if you don't have a Dreamcast, a GameCube, or a backwards compatible Wii, then this is a fine alternative. It's $8. Is it worth that? Well... if you're a big Sonic fan, sure. If you're just interested... wait for a sale maybe. It's not real high for a big name title like this, but I can't help feeling you could wait and get it cheaper. Sonic Adventure DX gets a 6/10.

reviewText:
I adored Sonic Adventure DX when I played it back on the gamecube. The game blew me away, and I loved almost every minute. The controls felt great, and the voice acting was just corny enough to make me laugh every time.

And the game is still pretty good. But sadly, many parts of this game have not aged well at all.

The voice acting is still hilariously corny, and the graphics have held up pretty well. However, there are parts of the game that just drone. The minigames interrupting the story, such as the plane shooter segments with Tails and the Sonic pinball minigame, just get in the way of the core gameplay.

Also, the game does not support widescreen and has permanant blue bars.

If you can look past the problems, Sonic Adventure is a pretty damn good game. The level design is still pretty good, the music is catchy and memorable, and the core gameplay as Sonic is really fun. But sadly, it's issues and flaws have made the game unbearable for me, despite my nostalgia.

Either way, it's still the same Dreamcast classic from over 15 years ago. It's fun, but don't be surpirsed if it's not nearly as great as you remember.

THE best 3D Sonic game ever released, without a doubt. Platforming of the highest order only hampered by the usual camera issues and some level glitches. Could have done without Big the cat and his awful fishing levels. Amy's gameplay is a bit ♥♥♥♥♥ but its far more bearable, particularly considering how well pulled of the rest are. The intertwining stories work brilliantly, particularly that of E-102 Gamma, and leave you with a sense of each individuals' perspective on the events. The loveable robot Gamma's levels are fun, not suffering from the slowing of the mech levels in SA2, and his story is almost tearjerking, especially at the end. 100% reccomended.

reviewText: Great game on Dreamcast, and after the latest update, great game on PC, definitely would recomend, 9/10
This game has its fair share of bugs, more often than not I find myself falling through the ground, but it's still one of the most enjoyable Sonic games I've played.

This game has... a lot of problems. But like all sonic games it has a weird and amazing charm to it. This game can get HILARIOUSLY bad at some points. But thats the fun of it! Most of all the stages are actually incredibly enjoyable. The cutscenes are so bad they're actually amazing. The story is... well a sonic story, but one of the better ones in my opinion. It's got its flaws (like all sonic games) but man its definitely silly to the millionth degree and incredibly enjoyable.

Sonic fan? Buy it.
Rare new Sonic Fan? Buy it, then go buy Sonic Adventure 2.
Not a Sonic fan? Buy it, and laugh at its silliness, (it's quite the ride).

The game is an excellent memory of how Dreamcast and gamecube games were great, even though it has it's flaws, and the screen is a bit buggy it's still worth buying it if you are a sonic fan, or if you had this game back when you were younger and you want to experience it again.
Although the remasterization of the game only changed a bit of the graphics, the game itself is still pretty easy, and some of the original bugs persist, even so it's still a game worth buying.

7/10

This is an interesting port. It's a mix of the gamecube and PSN/XBLA versions, however, it appears to take after the digital versions more.

It has an unfortunate glitch regarding not writing to the registry properly, however, once that is fixed up, controllers work well... And trust me, they are needed.

The game itself is not bad at all; though if you're not patient, Big's side of the story will REALLY be an annoyance at times. I myself never got the patience to fully complete the missions for him or so, in fact.

The story is there to help progress the game basically, and there are a few inconsistencies between all the characters; however, it does serve some backstory to the Echidna race, and further explanations of the Chaos Emeralds and the Master Emerald.

I'd say that this is a good game, once its issues are dealt with, which don't take long.

Pros:

-Easy to control, I wish recent sonic games would control this smoothly
-Straight foward action stages
-Good replayability in some stages with a animals, score, and a timer to challenge yourself later. Leader board would be cool but that'd be a huge stretch
-Able to play some of the gamegear games
-Chao Garden
-Fast paced stages
-Tons of minigames and Emblems to collect, giving something to do after beating the game
-Music is good (though that's a given in every Sonic game)
-Game can be reasonably punishing when messing up in a boss fight or stage which can give some level of challenge
-Tons of things to find in the adventure field to reward exploration

Cons:
-Voice acting sounds forced
-Story is a wreck
-A lot of plot-useless characters (Amy, Big, and Gamma)
-Chao Garden is really slippery
-Excessive amounts of grinding when buying stuff from the Black Market
-A lot of padding when trying to get to the true ending story (beat story mode with everyone)
-Having to fight Chaos 4" three different times is worse than going through an Auto-Scroll stage in a sidescroller
-Sky Chase Mini-game is insanely easy by just going to the bottom right corner and dodge everything
-Forgettable NPCs"

This is a very faithful port of Sonic Adventure DX to the PC, which is both good and bad. Good in that it'll be exactly how you remember it, but bad in that it'll be exactly how you remember it. This port brings no changes to the physics system, which can be sometimes janky depending on what you think the input should be versus what input the game wants, and the story still has the occasional odd moment that makes you wonder exactly why you are playing.

There is little issue getting this title to run on a Windows 7 machine unless you want to play full screen. The included configuration tool just doesn't work without adding a small registry key change that you can find in the Steam forums. Making matters worse, the full screen option is kind of a misnomer because the actual game play is boxed in by a border when playing on an wide screen monitor. I know the original game was meant for 4:3 displays, but it shouldn't take any effort at all to include varied resolution options on the PC (especially when the next game in the Sonic Adventure series has these options).

As for controls, a gamepad is certainly recommended, but it isn't unplayable without one. I actually found that I had an easier time lining Sonic up with lines of rings with the keyboard controls, but overall (considering this was originally a console game) it feels much more natural with a gamepad. This is the first fully 3D Sonic game, so the camera leaves something to be desired, but it doesn't impede gameplay most of the time. The camera is only a real nuisance when navigating the forest in the Mystic Ruins Adventure Field.

Like I stated before, this is a faithful port, so don't go into this expecting any kind of extra missions or features. The game's page from within Steam shows Achievements, but they actually do not work at all as of the writing of this review.

The story is hit and miss. I imagine most will play this once and never play it again. There are problems with the pacing given the way that they divided it between six playable characters. You get to experience the perspective of each character's place in the plot at large, but this means revisiting some scenes multiple times. It helps that the dialogue is slightly altered when playing as different characters, but this doesn't shake the feeling of, Been there
recommended: the delivery of some of the lines is particularly narmy
hoursPlayed: but the voice acting is otherwise acceptable (though Eggman's character actually benefits from the over the top performance). The most egregious example of "Been there
voteText: done that" by far is through the credits. The game ultimately has an ending that wraps everything up

votesFunny: so you won't find yourself wanting to rush through the levels anyways. The fishing levels really aren't any fun

column18: but neither were the ones in the 2D Sonic games. However

column21: but it is a great effort by the Dreamcast-era Sonic Team. They manage to successfully capture the mood of the plot and platforming mechanics of the 2D Sonic games in this initial 3D Sonic offering."

ahh..... the good ole days, back when it was just a simple 3d sonic game.\nNow the actual review. Sonic Adventure DX is an updated version that was originally made for the gamecube which was a remake of the original game on the SEGA Dreamcast which can now be played on the computer, is SEGA's first 3D Sonic game in the canon and continuty of sonic games and instead of just playing as sonic in multiple levels, you can play as other characters new and old as they have different abilities and upgrades. Tails, sonic's good ole pal, can fly short distances and can do a spin attack. Knuckles, sonic's long time rival, can glide and climb up walls (similar to how he played back in the day's of the gensis) but doesnt run around in levels to reach a goal, instead he looks for pieces of the master emerald. Amy Rose returns from SOnic CD, but is now playable, she is equipped with a hammer that can make here jump farther at a certain speed but in each level is being chased and must get to a balloon. A fat Cat named BIg makes his debut in this game, but doesnt run quickly or does anything that's very usefull, he just fishes, for a frog. next up is a robot made by Dr. Eggman, and by far the coolest in the game, E-102 Gamma shoots and makes it to his robot brothern..... and kills them.\nThis game is apart of my childhood as its the first game I've ever beaten, but Big's the only reason that it's fine if you don't complete the game. 8.5/10. mostly becuase of big that fat♥♥♥♥ of a cat.

Sure, it's glitchy, it has a horrible camera, the plot and voice acting is a joke, and you have to go fishing to unlock the final boss, but Sonic Adventure is still a cool and really fun game. It's my favorite Sonic game, and considering that Sonic is my favorite game series, I guess this is my favorite video game, period. I'm not sure why I like it so much. It takes a little getting used to, but once you do, the simple objective of getting from point A to point B as fast as possible while smashing any robots that get in your way is surprisingly engaging.\n\nThe different characters give different takes on this core objective, and most of them are pretty fun (if not quite as fun as Sonic). The best would probably be Tails (beat Sonic or Eggman to point B), simply because he is so close to breaking the game that you can skip entire sections of the level without touching the ground if you're good enough. Gamma is pretty fun too, as the focus of his levels is essentially blow crap up." Even Knuckles' treasure hunting levels aren't as much of a drag as they are in the sequel

reviewText: Mario may be a cool character but Tails is clearly the better animal of the bunch in the mushroom kingdom. May be an oldie and not so goldie, but why not take trip back to the past of the days where you had a love for Hedgehogs. I rate it 7 flying eggshells.
This is Really good and i recomend it!

THE best 3D Sonic game ever released, without a doubt. Platforming of the highest order only hampered by the usual camera issues and some level glitches. Could have done without Big the cat and his awful fishing levels. Amy's gameplay is a bit ♥♥♥♥♥ but its far more bearable, particularly considering how well pulled of the rest are. The intertwining stories work brilliantly, particularly that of E-102 Gamma, and leave you with a sense of each individuals' perspective on the events. The loveable robot Gamma's levels are fun, not suffering from the slowing of the mech levels in SA2, and his story is almost tearjerking, especially at the end. 100% reccomended.

This game is absolutely fantastic. Worth every cent you will spend on it. It is fun, very replayable, and will last you quite a long time. However, if you aren't huge on sonic to begin with, it may not be for you. If you are a fan of sonic, I implore you to get it right now, if you haven't already.

This is game is a love and hate relationship

SO HERES A REVIEW,SPOILERS AHEAD

Story:The story of Adventure was that Eggman was planning to get all 7 chaos emeralds to give to Chaos so Chaos can destroy the main city in the game,Station Square.While every character has a diffrent story to them they all take place in the same timeline.

Sonic:Sonic stages are alright but (this may sound stupid) they too fast,you sometimes sprint into things that you couldn't see.But for Sonics story it was alright I guess.Sonic one day was just chillin' until Tails crashed his plane on the beach.Eventually when Sonic finds Tails he tells Sonic about a chaos emerald he used to power his plane,eventually Eggman comes and steals the emeralds that tails had.Soon enough Eggman gets 6 of the emeralds that he needs but Sonic saves the day.

Tails:Tails stages were my favourite because they were soooooo easy,you could just fly to the end of the stage,but they were fun.Tails story was good too,Tails crashes his ship and meets sonic.Later on Tails has to beat Egg walker (A robot that eggman made to destroy station square).

Knuckles:.Knuckles' stages involve you to go around the stage and pick up parts of the master emerald,this can be annoying.Knuckles story is decent,Knuckles protects the master emerald from anyone,but sadly Chaos takes parts out of it and Knuckles has to find it in order to make his island float again

Amy:Amy makes you escape from a robot chasing her called Zero" amy goes quite slow
date: making it hard to navigate the stages.Amy's story is...uhhh
recommended: Amy is relaxing at Station Square until Zero appears and tries to steal a bird that she finds.Soon enough she gets captured until a robot called "E102 Gamma" lets her out.\n\nBig the cat:Even though everyone says that Big the cat sucks
hoursPlayed: he wasnt that bad.His story is terrible
voteText: Big the cat is relaxing (This game has a lot of characters relaxing if you had not noticed) until Chaos takes over Bigs pet frog (Froggy) so then big the cat has to find froggy.\n\nE102 Gamma:The Gamma stages were VERY short and his story is (In my opinion) the best story.Gamma was made by Eggman to find the rest of the chaos emeralds and to find Froggy

reviewText: Sonic Adventure is a REVOLUTIONARY NEW 3D platformer Dreamcast game from 1999 with cheesy cutscenes and glitches. Yes, you can go fast and even fish.

A nostalgia trip from childhood. Embrace the awful graffics, aimless wandering through the adventure fields, the corny melodrama of the story, the cringe-worth voice acting and animation, and the satisfaction of beating it 100%. In the spirit of all true Sonic games, this one also pimps the selling point of having you to go as fast as possible -- while containing levels that make it virtually impossible to do so. In retrospect, this game doesn't stand the test of time like Mario 64 and Zelda: Ocarina of Time, but it's fun in its own right. For $7.99 you will be entertained. Well, at least until you have to play Big's storyline. God it's awful.
Nostalgic game ^^

reviewText: THIS GAME SUCKS.  WHY WOULD YOU WANT TO PLAY AS SONIC WHEN YOU CAN PLAY AS HIM IN A NANOSUIT!  WTF SEGA!! THEY SHOULD KNOW IF THEY PUT THAT IN THEY WOULD HAVE OUTSOLD DEAGLES!  ♥♥♥♥ IT THE ATARI 2600 VERSION OF THIS GAME IS BETTER!  HERE THAT KEYBLADE MARIO IS ♥♥♥♥ COMPARED TO SONIC IN A NANOSUIT!

To be perfectly honest, this game is absolute garbage. The voice acting is terrible, the animations are godawful, the physics are pretty broken, there are many areas where you can clip out of bounds(sometimes without even intending to), and there are many points where scripted sequences will just break and you'll get shot out of the map like a speeding bullet.... but I still recommend this game, because despite being garbage, it's very fun garbage. Plus when you look past all the flaws, the level design is actually pretty good. Whether or not you have nostalgia for it, the game is enjoyable. I recommend playing with the Better Sonic Adventure DX patch, along with the Beta Windy Valley restoration mod.

Oh Sonic Adventure... if you had a DreamCast, this will bring back memories. I believe this was the first Sonic game they did in 3D, and they did great with the technology they had at the time.

I'll admit, the game is pretty cheesy, and the camera hates you just as much as you'll hate it, but the best part of this game is the Chao Garden. Oh and you don't have those awesome memory cards from the DreamCast that you could play games on, which sucks but hey, SONIC! Always a plus side for those die-hard Sonic fans like myself.

It's not a HARD game, but there are parts where you will be playing and want to rage, but even those wtf" moments are enjoyable."
The worst part is the camera. Besides that I just jumped off a train and survived 11/10 better than GTA V.

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite games of all time. It's buggy, it's broken, it's frustrating, it's laughably dated, the cutscenes are the opposite of intense (except for the kickass intro) but it's still incredibly fun. It's simply nothing more: it's a fun game. I'm currently about 66% of the way through my first time playing it on Steam. I've played it on Gamecube at least five or more times, though. My last run was a mere few months ago.

The game is sort of short (it's like 20 or so hours on a normal run, I think?) but it's a very nice experience. It helped lay down some of the rules for future 3D Sonic games, most notably, the Homing Attack, which was underused in this title if you ask me, but future games make full use of it. In fact, this game had a lot of new stuff, some of which I wish became series staples, like Adventure Fields and upgrades.

I'm sure there's better reviews for this game right now than mine, so I'll just leave it at the personal opinions I just expressed. It's a really fun game for being so buggy and it has Chao Gardens, which is great. It's probably the #1 game I want an HD remaster of.

P.S. My Chao grew up to be emo and I would like parenting tips on how to raise my emo child

reviewText: Sonic Adventure is a REVOLUTIONARY NEW 3D platformer Dreamcast game from 1999 with cheesy cutscenes and glitches. Yes, you can go fast and even fish.

To be perfectly honest, this game is absolute garbage. The voice acting is terrible, the animations are godawful, the physics are pretty broken, there are many areas where you can clip out of bounds(sometimes without even intending to), and there are many points where scripted sequences will just break and you'll get shot out of the map like a speeding bullet.... but I still recommend this game, because despite being garbage, it's very fun garbage. Plus when you look past all the flaws, the level design is actually pretty good. Whether or not you have nostalgia for it, the game is enjoyable. I recommend playing with the Better Sonic Adventure DX patch, along with the Beta Windy Valley restoration mod.

Sonic Adventure DX is a trip down memory lane for me. I never got in touch with the Dreamcast version and only experienced the DX Version every time i played this game. Back then, i didn't really mind this port/version, despite it's reputation, and i still think to this day it is not too bad. The entire gameplay is rather solid (except for Big and Amy most of the time), story wise it is one of the better ones in the entire modern Sonic Franchise with the most character development.

But this PC port is giving me a really tough time. Here, the downsides the DX version brought are even worse here, with bugs left and right, extremely bad camera issues, very weird controller mapping, audio errors and so on. I even had the problem at one boss fight that the entire fight got glitched and i couldn't finish the boss. After installing the fanmade Patch (which didn't work for me sadly) and uninstalling it, the fight suddenly went without problems. Needless to say, this whole thing still costed me 1-2 hours of my time and it was rather annoying.

When the game works, it's the same enjoyable game i remember from back then, with usually short and very nice stages usually lasting 2-3 minutes. Every story is usually fairly short and you only have to endure Bigs lame fishing games and Amys slow as molases platforming for a short while.

Also the game offers a lot to do even after, but nowhere as deep or exciting as Sonic Adventure 2.

Speaking of said title, i can highly recommend the second game to this one hands down. The gameplay is better, the story and presentation are better even if it has more plotholes, it has tons more content and the challenge level is also higher. And for people who only play for the Chao Garden anyway, get SA2, the Garden is a way more enjoyable experience.


In Conclusion, i am not completely sure if i can recommend this or not. The normal game i can recommend without a doubt, it's still a pretty good entry in the Sonic Series even with it's downsides. But the Steam version is so unbelieveable broken at parts it really discouraged me to play further sometimes.

Get it when it's on sale.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. It's buggy, it's broken, it's frustrating, it's laughably dated, the cutscenes are the opposite of intense (except for the kickass intro) but it's still incredibly fun. It's simply nothing more: it's a fun game. I'm currently about 66% of the way through my first time playing it on Steam. I've played it on Gamecube at least five or more times, though. My last run was a mere few months ago.

The game is sort of short (it's like 20 or so hours on a normal run, I think?) but it's a very nice experience. It helped lay down some of the rules for future 3D Sonic games, most notably, the Homing Attack, which was underused in this title if you ask me, but future games make full use of it. In fact, this game had a lot of new stuff, some of which I wish became series staples, like Adventure Fields and upgrades.

I'm sure there's better reviews for this game right now than mine, so I'll just leave it at the personal opinions I just expressed. It's a really fun game for being so buggy and it has Chao Gardens, which is great. It's probably the #1 game I want an HD remaster of.

P.S. My Chao grew up to be emo and I would like parenting tips on how to raise my emo child

Sonic Adventure is a tricky game to judge. When it was first released back in 2001, it was loved by almost all. I myself have fond memories of playing it on the Gamecube. But some games just do not age well, and unfortunately, Sonic Adventure is one of them.

The game's camera often has a difficult time focusing on the characters and actions, thus making even the simplest of jumps an annoyance to be repeated again and again. The controls are also frequently difficult to work with, epsecially in situations requiring accuracy and a bit of finess. The story which is told from the perspective of several different characters is a boring and cliche-ridden droll, complete with events that often don't sync up. But it is admirable that it at least trys to present some character development and lore.

The game's highlights are its level design, which can truly be a joy to traverse through every so often, and to a lesser extent, its music. But neither of these traits are enough to make an enjoyable experience.

Overall Sonic Adventure is a clunky and boring game that only has a few inklings of entertainment sprinkled thoughout its entirety. Unless you're a dedicated Sonic fan or just want to experience the character's first true foray into the third dimension, I wouldn't play this game.

This game is a true platformer. I came across this beauty when looking for SA2 as I heard great reviews, and ooh, the Chao Garden. However, I got the games mixed up. I was super mad and felt horrible like I wasted money but as I got farther in as Knuckles I absolutely LOVED it. All characters have good mechanics, so you arent playing the same thing (but screw big and amy anyways I actually loved E-102 Gamma.) It has an good, explained story all set out but the chronological order of all the characters stories may be mixed up. The main characters, the main trio, the main pilots, the main people, the main players, the main i dont know, Sonic, Knuckles and Tails are where the story is mainly at. These characters have longer stories and more mechanics to them. You will love playing as these 3, but the other 3 not so much as the main. However, since the game was originally for the Sega Dreamcast some of the cutscenes are strange, with weird mouth movements and slow walking. However, this should not be a problem at all unless your a whiny casual, as the gameplay is better. As Sonic the Hedgehog, you go straight-out speedy 3d platforming, in many levels. As Tails, you race Sonic (and Eggman on the last level)  to get to the end and grab the Chaos emerald before Sonic does. (for Eggman, its to a rocket.) As Knuckles, you have to locate 3 Master Emerald pieces in very large sub-overworlds. You have to use your locater which will flash and change colors as you get closer, but can cause some VERY tedious moments. As Amy, you have to escape from one of Eggman's robots to the end of a level and grab an escape, using a Piko-Piko hammer as a weapon. As Big the Cat, you..... fish. Yeah, you just fish a frog out of the pond, Literally. Just go to a pond in a level and fish Froggy out. Seriously. Thats it. As E-102 Gamma you are one of Eggman's robots. You have to go through many levels where you shoot things like a 8-year old who just drank 10 5-hour energy drinks playing COD. The more things you shoot, the more time you get, and at the end you have to face another robot in the true levels. All these characters get atleast 2 powerups which can help them power up a default move, learn a new move or give them something to help finish levels better, in which some of these powerups are needed and some are optional.

In the end, you play as Super Sonic against the main antagonist, Perfect Chaos. You use the powers of the 7 Chaos Emeralds to defeat Perfect Chaos. As you progress through the skies, your ring counter goes down. You must keep it above zero or you will fail the level. This is a balance of fun and tedious, but mostly fun.

In the end, this is a great game for Sonic fans and just about anyone, especcialy platformer fans. I would totally reccomend and play for a very long time, as the levels have great replayability since you can do Mission Mode, Trials for medals, and replay levels for new times and scores. Overall, out of 10 I would give it a 9.

Also, in the end when you collect all medals, you get a Metal Sonic skin for Sonic.
Awesome.

reviewText:
I've only played the Steam version for a bit now, but I can say that it made the transition to PC very wel. It also brings along a ton of new unlockable extra's!
It brings back a lot of memories from playing on my Dreamcast in the late '90s and this was one of it's best titles!

The game automaticly detects the Xbox 360 controller and the controls feel really good. I recommend setting the camera controls from the bumpers to the right analog stick. The camera is still very sluggish compared to more modern titles, but it gets the job done.

The graphics haven't really been updated but there is support for HD resolution and it definitly looks better than before. Some 2D object don't handle this upscaling as well as the polygons but it has still aged very well!

Absolutely the best 3D sonic ever made! I recommend getting this with the Dreamcast Collection when it is on sale. You also get three other great titles with Crazy Taxi being another one of my Dreamcast favorites. Even though I'm so much in to them, Space Channel 5 and Bass Fishing are also very good.

reviewText:
I played this for the Gamecube before and wanted to play this game again for the PC. Odd to say I now own this copy, but the question is this: is this version of the game worth it?

Honestly, it depends. If you already own a console version, I'd stick with those since they're pretty much perfect for being Dreamcast ports. If you already own a PC version of this title (2004), you should stick with that since it is by far the best version out there for one thing: Mod support.

It is odd for a Steam version of Sonic Adventure DX to be... well, once again a port of a console version of an another console title that it originated from. By now this game should have graphical improvements and additional content, but here it's a step back from the 2004 PC version. This product seemed to have missing features that the console versions had so why a downgrade? Who knows...

And that's not all, of all the ports out there, this one is the least accurate version. People claimed to have missing textures and missing sound effects here and there. It depends on what kind of rig you have. This probably may be a sign of a rushed port just to grab some extra cash. So far this sounds like it may not be worth getting for a watered-down port that doesn't do what it should've done.

The worst part? No mod support for the Steam version. This is a deal breaker when the original PC version supported it.

That all sounds like it's not worth owning, but here in 2014, talanted dudes found a solution to restore this version to be the best version again like the original ten years back. With them, I think this game feels fresh again and honestly, it's fun. Oh and it's possible to achieve 4K here, it's beautiful. For a more interesting twist, try using multiple monitors as one ... it's pretty weird. Unless you don't care to mod the Steam version, I'd go with the console versions.

In short: On its own, Sonic Adventure DX on Steam is a not-so-great port, but one clever mod to change the game can make this one just as great like the old.

Its sequel is quite a lot more fun when it comes to the Chao gardens (which adds on quite a lot more hours of gameplay), but this game is definitely a game worth buying.

reviewText: Sonic adventure is a very good game. It is over a decade old. Sonic adventure was the most critically aclaimed sega dreamcast game scoring a 9.0 of 10 and was soon ported to the gamecube.In this game you take control of Sonic,Tails,Knuckles,Amy,Big,and a robot named E-102 GAMMA. Each character plays differently,Sonic has the classic get to the goal playstyle. Tails is racing sonic to the goal. Knuckles is trying to get the pieces of the master emerald to restore it.Amy is trying to outrun a robot. Big...well Big...he umm...fishes for a frog ( :P ). Gamma just flies around,shooting the heck out of things.This game is easily my favorite sonic game I give it a 9.5 out of 10 because there are a few plotholes. Aidan out!

reviewText:
For Sonic's first true jump into the 3D world, it did a fine job to bring a great game to the table at the time, but many set backs and flaws keep it from being a great game today. I guess what I'm trying to say is that this game has aged.  It's obvious by now that the best parts about this game are the main trio's portions of the game. I'll go ahead and say this right now, the classic series are superior in quality in terms of gameplay. If you're into the nostalgic aspect, go ahead and give the game a try once again like you did with your Dreamcast, but if you're getting into the series, give it a go if you're willing to go for the whole game, because I can't guarantee you'll enjoy the entire experience.

Bad: The animation during cutscenes are sloppy and downright horrible. The voice acting is questionable as well. Amy's portions are slow and dull, Gamma is a shooting fest, and Big...... The story overall is meh. Each character has their own respected stories, but none of them are really that intriguing and the overall story focusing on Chaos is just executed poorly. Sonic gets Eggman with Tails, Knuckles finds the emerald pieces, Amy helps a bird, Gamma saves his fellow robots, and Big fishes. This all leads up to Eggman using a water creature that uses the emeralds to become huge and destroy Station Square. No, There's no need to use the /spoiler because in the end what really matters is everything else.

Good: Sonic's gameplay is chock full of exploration and contains fast paced platforming. Tails and Knuckles are basically the same, they just have less stages. I don't mind the emerald hunting much in this game because it's done pretty well. unlike sa2 None of the stages between these three feel like a chore or take 50k years to finish. Also, this game gives Sonic the BEST control he's ever had in 3D. The music is AMAZING. I ♥♥♥♥ING LOVE this soundtrack to death.

Because this isn't a full fledged review, I may be jumping the gun a bit here but, this game has aged. I can't guarantee that everyone will enjoy this game in the state it's in, but remember this is a decade old. The best parts are only half the game, and that can be a problem for some people. I say, if you've always been a Sonic fan like me, go for it, if you're getting into the series, go for Generations or even the Classic series, then come back to this if you want. If you're curious or just don't care, go for it, you may really enjoy it.

TL DR; It may be ♥♥♥♥ for some people, but for others it may be a gem, it depends on your tastes. So go play a Sonic game unanimously considered good before you come back to this.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: One of my favorites of the Dreamcast Collection.  I bought this game when I first got my Dreamcast.  There of course is some issues with the game first off the bad camera angles and the game plays in a 4:3 cropped screen with a border.  Sega has also removed all the special content from this version of DX which was available in the original PC and Gamecube release.  Of course that content would be Sonic The Hedgehog Game Gear games and other minor content.   If you can get passed those flaws you'll enjoy this game. I of course had to share the flaws first cause that is what everybody looks for in a review.  The good points to the game though is this is the first Sonic The Hedgehog game in 3D.  The graphics were ahead of its time when the game originally got released for the Dreamcast.  Today it may not be as nice as most games but its still a good eye catcher and very colorful.    If you can get passed those flaws you'll enjoy this game.  There is different characters to choose from and each one containing their own story.  The game still has the speed of the originals and so much more have fun with the mini games as well.

reviewText:
Sonic finally managed to succesfully make the transition to 3D with this game, Sonic Adventure. I first played this on my Dreamcast and was blown away by the (then) detailed graphics... and the unbelievably bad voice overs.
It had beautiful and diverse vistas, great action scenes (remember the Orca scene ?), some cool boss fights and multiple characters (which I personally didn't really like).
Sure, it was no Super Mario 64 in the end but it definitely had some excellent moments back then.

[Rating: 78/100]

reviewText:
This is a great game if you like playing sub-par games. I'm not being a jerk, I LOVE playing buggy games with iffy controls and unfortunate camera angles. So many things can go hilariously wrong; I've fallen through the ground, had to cheat just to progress through parts of the game that could not be accessd otherwise, and even seen Sonic moonwalk.

All that said, this game is still very playable. It can be beat in about 4-5 hours and is very enjoyable all the way through. You can play as other characters as you meet them in the main story, but after finishing Sonic's quest I was kind of burnt out. The writing is obviously generic and easy for kids to understand, but the cutscenes have a certain throw logic out the window" feel to them.

This game is a classic and it's sequel is just as good and less buggy. Enjoy these Sonic games from before the great debacle of '06. Back when Sonic's attitude was tolerable and he wasn't crushing on hman girls."

reviewText:
[UPDATE: I wrote this review almost a year ago. Due to a few people apparently disagreeing with me, it may very well be the case that they've fixed the controller camera bug and resolution/fullscreen settings. I don't know because I can't be bothered reinstalling when I can just play on disc instead.]

I love the game but this port is terrible.

From what I understand, the original came out on the Dreamcast, then was ported to Gamecube. The PC disc version (the one I own and use) was a port of the GC version, and is good aside from a couple of glitches. Now, since then, the GC version has been ported to XBOX marketplace. Apparently it is this version which was ported to be on Steam. I am not usually one to complain when it comes to video games but this is just absolute garbage.

The first thing I noticed was the lack of fullscreen (well, any graphics options at all). I mean, come on, that is something every single video game should have. I have played many completely unfunded indie games and not one of them I have played has lacked the most basic feature of being able to go fullscreen. The game itself is in a tiny resolution (taking up about 30% of my screen) surrounded by an ugly blue patterned border inside of a window, which is really, really offputting.

The next issue was controls. I plugged in my controller and all of a sudden, the camera was eternally rotating to the right, and there was nothing I could do. This was never an issue in the original PC port. In the end, I decided to use my keyboard as I did when I played through the game back when I was younger.

As you can tell, I didn't get very far. I promptly uninstalled this pile of rubbish and got out my original disc to use that instead. I would suggest you do the same if you want to play this amazing game: one of the best 3D Sonic games and a massive chunk of my childhood that was sadly ruined by one of the worst port jobs I've seen in a long while.

reviewText:
I absolutley love this game. Many consider it the best sonic game ever. But i'll be honest, this PC port of the game is horrible. There are bugs EVERYWHERE.

I'll start with the Resolution. a recent update allows you to change the resolution beyond 720p. This sounds great, but it actually breaks many graphics. Mostly with the UI and HUD. Some things will appear WAY too small and sometimes even appears in the wrong area. Even worse though there are flickering and even spazzing glitches that happen regardless of the resolution. Graphics aren't the only problem tough.

Many sounds are also broken. Sometimes a sound won't play, even worse sometimes a sound won't STOP playing. I've especially had this issue in the chao garden when a chao goes swiming. Even when i get them out of the water the spashing sound plays on an endless loop. Twinkle park has volume issues as well. A lot of noises are either too loud or too quiet. You often can't even hear the music.

I've heard this game has slowdown issues as well, i haven't really had a problem, but maybe that's because i have a pretty good PC. But a heads up just in case.

Overall this really feels like a shoddy emulation rather than a true port. If you've played this game before and want a little nostalgia, you may be willing to handle it. But if you haven't played it before, i say skip it.

reviewText:
Do not buy this awful port of Sonic Adventure. The game runs very poorly and has a lot of graphical issues that did not exist on the Gamecube version from 2003. While they did include an update to allow higher resolution as well as AA the game still kept it's crappy 4:3 aspect ratio. Now you have two bars on the side of your screen. They're not even black, they're freaking blue!

That's not even the worst part about it. It doesn't include the Game Gear games nor does the freecam work anymore. Think about it, the game already had a terrible camera, but now it's even worse because you can't use the analog stick to adjust the screen. Let that sink in for a bit.

Until SEGA decides to fix this mess don't waste your money on this game. Buy it on the Gamecube. It run and play better.

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure DX for PC is just so, amazingly... ok. It just trys to be something absolutly huge for the franchise, mixing dramatic storytelling with the rush of Sonic gameplay, and yeah, at the time and on the right hardware, this was revolutionary. Its just plain awful today.

The advancements in PC gaming make the attempts for story telling, and the technology used for this effect just laughable. Seriously, the developers of the PC version must have LOW expectations. Your first playthrough of this game (all campaigns) will be memorable for years to come, but not in a good way.  Why?

Because this PC port is complete ♥♥♥. Missing button presses was a frequent problem through my experience, no matter how many different keyboards and computers I played on. (tested on 5, btw) For example, During the final boss fight of Amy's campaign, during phase 3, I game-overed 3 times from full lives because of the missed presses. In the fight, you have to jump over an obstacle. In my experience, Amy jumped probably 3/4 of the time. Eventually I got so badly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at the game, I borrowed a second USB keyboard just to double my button presses.

This problem was only present in the Boss fights. There is literally no reason for this.

Why do I say thats its OK then? Well, Sonic Adventure DX is on the fence on being Good or Bad. The cornyness of the cinematics makes it funny and good, but only seconds later, a glitch where you are thrown uncontrolably off a stage by a pickup, losing a life and possibly game-overing you makes it bad. This effect (and unfortunatly glitch) happens frequently.

If you are curious, wait untill it's like $1 in a sale before you buy. Just the hours alone and ONLY the hours alone playing this game would justify that price. If you are on the fence, just don't.

Here's hoping Sonic Adventure 2 isn't this broken.

reviewText:
This game , as the first sonic 3D Game is nice to play. There are lots of bugs but not too annoying (except for the camera high as f**k). A bit too easy in my view but level design may compensate it. There's also an awesome soundtrack.

And, last but not least, Sonic is really dumb in the story,  too slack, but it can be fun for some to see it.

The sonic's story is done in less than 3hours, but it can be entertaining to finish all the characters' stories.

So, what you have to keep in mind is : be indulgent, fun is there but animation and actors are over exagerated.
Good level design, epic music, here is my final score : 7.5/10

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure was originally created for Dreamcast at the end of the '90s. The Sonic X Japanese anime was based on the story of the 2 Sonic Adventure game and it has continued in Sonic Adventure 2, but lets speak about the game.

The Story
As I said it the Sonic X series was based on the Adventure Games. The plot is that there is a monster called Chaos who gain his power by eating all the chaos emeralds. Sonic and friends need to stop Dr. Robotnik alias Eggman who is trying to find all of the chaos emeralds to make Chaos invulnerable and with that power destroy Station Square and build a new place there called Robotnikland.

Gameplay
The game has 6 playable charachters know as: Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Amy, Big and E-102. All of it has differint gameplay style but the worst of all is Big the Cat. Sega is tried to show how awesome is the Dreamcast console so they added a fishing part to the game and to finish the game with 100% you need to clear that Story too. At the last story you unlock Super Sonic and if you finished collecting all of the emblems than you unlock Metal Sonic too. The camare physics is somewhere breaks so watch out with that.

Soundtrack
The game has the good and old Crush 40 songs that every Sonic fan loves. I do not want to speak about this too much, try out the game or just listen to it you will know what I meant.

Pros: -6 characters
-Level designs
-Soundtrack
-A game that adapts the animes Story (if you want the full check out Sonic Adventure 2 too)
-The Dreamcast version and the 2004 port
-Character design
-Collectable upgrades

Cons: -The 2011 port of the game
-Big the Cat

I do prefer for everybody to try the game out and share it with this generation because they do grow up on Sonic games like Lost World and Sonic Boom. We do not want that, yeah Sonic Fans?

My scores for the is a: 7/10

reviewText:
I never got the chance to beat this game way back in the day when it was new on the dreamcast: I had rented it and didn't get all that far in the weekend i had it out from, the now extinct, blockbuster. Finally I can say I did it. Another thing off of the bucket list

If you have never played this game, and are buying it just to buy it- remember this game is old. by today's standards the graphics are laughable. Seams are in plain view, and nearly everything is a photo-texture, one that repeats so much you might be reminded of a checkerboard looking at the ground. Round objects are only round in theory, so that tires may look more like bolts than wheels. The animation is odd, and looks like sonic is at all times dancing, or looking for his next drug fix like an addict on the street corner.
But, when this game came out, i remember how beautiful it looked. An early game in the 3d arena, this was at one time cutting edge. so give it some slack if you weren't around then.

This game requires you to play as the characters other than sonic to complete the game, and honestly like a lot of sonic games as of late in the sonic series you are kind of left wondering why?". A lot of the other stories feel rushed and personally i find Amy and Bigs' gameplay to be unfun. Bigs plays as fishing simulator
date: and Amy is slow.... neither of these are reason i would play a sonic game.\nThe other characters aren't so much unfun to play as

reviewText:
It feels a little weird sometimes, but it's a sonic game.

Cons
-----
-Physics engine gets really REALLY ♥♥♥♥ing bizzare sometimes.
-THIS version can be a glitchy mess sometimes (more than usual).
-Any section involving running along a wall is shaky at best (neat when it works though).
-Knuckles levels.
-Big levels would be more fun if the fishing mechanics weren't so clunky.
-Most of the bosses are a chore.
-Overworlds were a nice idea, but a lot of them are just kind of boring honestly.

Pros
-----
+Sonic levels are fun.
+Tails levels are alright (and he's not in a stupid ♥♥♥♥ing mech).
+Amy levels are fun, but I wish there were more of them (nobody agrees with me).
+Gamma levels are fun, but I wish they were longer (everyone agrees with me).
+Knuckles levels are less annoying than SA2 (I guess that's something?).
+Voice acting is so bad it's good.
+Egg Viper is cool.
+Final boss is ok.
+Music is good.

Better than SA2. Has issues, but is actually fun to play most of the time.
If you don't have a dreamcast, this is a good enough alternative.

reviewText:
DX Has not aged well to say the least.  If you're like me, Someone who grew up on the game and wants to revisit it, It's worth a purchase so you can give it a new home in your steam library and replay it for some nostalgic weekends.

However, If you're a younger customer who's curious what the game was like, you're better off watching a review or playthrough of it. Most mechanics are annoying and time consuming to grasp, even for people who played it as a kid, So someone used to the pamperment newer 3D games have in design, this wonky old game will seem very broken and incomplete.

Some of the worst issues are the camera, horrendous cuscenes (which seem to still be in 30fps, while the game itself runs 60) and obviously subpar graphics. As i said, if you want an idea of the adventure franchise, go play the Second game. The stories (from my memory) hardly converge anyways.

All of that said, i grew up playing the original version on the dreamcast, and picked up the DX when it came out aswell. I was not a smart child and instead of saving my games and consoles up, i traded them in for the next thing (it was the most cost effective for my family). That's why i felt i should pick it up for steam, and I'm happy i did. The memories rushed back, The only thing that could have made it better was if my older brother still lived here so i could watch him play.

But yeah. Game isn't great. It's a nice buy if you want to revisit the past.

reviewText:
An okay game for the first of the Sonic Adventure series. It has bugs and holes that were not patched or patched well when the game was initially released. However, it still plays well despite feeling like a prototype.

P.S. Play this game with a controller. It is a lot easier compared to using keyboard controls.

P.P.S. Play Sonic Adventures 2 if playing a buggy game is not feasible. The sequel is polished and is overall a better playing experience.

reviewText:
This game has aged badly. Hell, it had aged badly by the time the Gamecube port was out. But it still holds a strange sort of charm and sense of nostalgia in its awfulness. My recommendation comes with a huge caveat, however. Buy it only if you can get it for dirt cheap, and if you are a masochist like me and find pleasure in playing bad games. If good games age like fine wine, Sonic Adventure has aged like milk.

Pros:
Evokes nostlagia for fans of the franchise.
Humour abounds in the game's badness.
Plays more competently than some later entries in the Sonic franchise.
Japanese voice acting is available, and is much more pleasing to the ear.
Cons:
50% of the game (Amy, Big, Gamma) is a total bore, and completing their mundane tasks are mandatory for finishing the game.
Controls like you're driving a car with one tire.
Camera tends to go a bit spastic in several areas, and wrestling it into position can be a chore.
Laughably bad English dubbing, featuring lifeless, extremely repetitive dialogue, as if the voice actors had a running bet on how badly they could perform their lines.
Boss fights with all of the complexity of a warm bowl of tomato soup.
$8.79? I think I paid maybe $20 for the Gamecube port, and that was in 2003! Wait for a sale if you must have this game.

reviewText:
I used to love this game about 15 years ago.  But it's clearly not aged well.  Awkward controls, wonky physics, horrible camera, numerous bugs and glitches, poor graphics, and the story is underminded by some of the worst cutscenes in any game, complete with horrible voice acting.

Only Sonic and Tails' stories are any fun to play.  Knuckles, Amy and Gamma's levels are boring, and Big's is FISHING.  Seriously, who thought that fishing in a Sonic game would be an okay idea?

This is a game that has not survived the test of time.  But so many people refuse to accept this purely because of their nostalgia.

An overrated game if there ever was one.

reviewText:
Unless you're a hardcore fan or have genuine nostalgia for this specific game, please don't ever pay money for this game on it's own. Even I played this back in the day, and it was baaaad even then.

While there is some cheesy(good) music and this game is a little landmark in gaming history, it is has so much badly designed progression between missions, awful animation and cameras, cheese from beyond the cheeseveil, and overly long-winded and hollow gameplay.

This isn't a game you buy to 'play', this is like a digital museum ticket where you pay to look at a bit of gaming history. Yeah, it's an interactive museum, but this is still a fossil that was dead on arrival.

reviewText:
Wow. So what do we say about this game? Basically it is unplayable. The team that made this game wasn't writing code. They were using Infinite Monkey Theorem. You know the theory where an army of monkeys given enough time hitting random keys on a keyboard will eventually form coherent words and at some indescribable point in time will produce all of Shakespeare's plays? It's like that.

I loved Sonic growing up. I wanted to like this game, I really did. But this is something else. This is what happens when you port a game without caring about the end product or the consumer. This is a giant metaphorical middle finger to everyone that has ever had a moment of joy in their lives while playing a Sonic game.

If you can get it to run you're off to a great start. Even better is understanding the control layout from the crappy diagram of an offbrand imaginary Sega controller when you plug in your 360 gamepad. This game has so many glitches it makes Duke Nukem Forever look like Star Citizen.

I can't jump off of a spring or do a spin without falling through an invisible floor or getting bounced back to the beginning of the map. I mean I can. You can possibly play the game by memorizing every 256 possible glitches per level. Maybe you are a connoisseur of terrible games and it is in your blood to finish this game. You are a better man/woman/seal than me. However I cannot continue. I can't carry on with this because I have a life to live and we have to let go of our obsessions. So if you will forgive me I am going to go burn my hard drive for having let me suffer through this experience.

reviewText:
The real question you should be asking yourself before you purchase this game: Has it aged well?

The answer: NO.

To be honest, I first played Sonic Adventure on the gamecube. No dreamcast here, I didn't even know the game was a thing until I bought it on the gamecube and thought it was awful. Only after playing through half of it originally did I learn it was actually an older game ported and "remastered" for the gamecube, and then I excused it for some of it's faults. But in 201X, there's really no reason at all to play this game unless you are either a die hard fan of sonic/sonic adventure or you want to see a historical game showcasing where sonic started to go wrong.

What is wrong with this game?

-Awful Camera: The game's camera is bipolar and will sometimes be really nice to you and show you everything you need to see or jitter around and clip through the ground essentially putting your life in the hands of the level design

-Level Design: Speaking of level design, it's bad. There are multiple paths to get where you want to go which is nice, but there are so many instances of the game giving you massive speed boosts only to stop you 5 feet later, or worse- kill you. It seems like the developers couldn't decide if they wanted you to go fast like traditional sonic games, or to make a slow platforming adventure.

-Controls: Slippery and too fast. See level design. Play the Egg Carrier stage as sonic and cry as the controls rapidly change as the camera goes all over the place.

-Big the Cat Stages: Even people who love this game can't defend these.

Despite all this, not all is bad. Some of the levels are legitimately cool, I enjoyed the beach, casino, and temple levels very much. The ring dash is satisfying, and with upgrades, isn't annoying to use. Some characters here are really interesting, and while the robot isn't all that fun to play it's interesting to see a mech that has a machine gun in a sonic game.

TL;DR: Don't bother buying unless you're buying it for like 1 dollar or you're a huge fan of the game

reviewText:
As you can see, I have not played that much of this game. Therefore my no recommendation may be a bit unfair.

With this said, I can not recommend this game.

At first I got this game because I had this random feeling that I wanted to play Sonic. As a child I remembered playing this game and enjoying it. I did enjoy the game a bit but for the most part the game annoyed me.

Lets start with the positive.

The music was not to bad. It is what you would suspect out of a game like Sonic. Some parts of the different courses were entertaining. The graphics seemed good for the time when it was made. The controls made sense and for the most part responded on a Xbox 360 Controller. Unlockable characters with their own content, although I have not delved into that content. I mostly played as Sonic.

And for the bad...

Parts of the levels did not feel like your usual Sonic levels. For example they added some confusing exploring elements to them. I remember getting lost in a level not knowing where to go. The levels also got confusing because the camera kept getting stuck on walls and what ever else it could get stuck on. Also there was a lot of obstacles that I felt slowed down the overall pace of the level, which kind of annoyed me. In Sonic games I suspect to go fast not slow. Its fine to have obstacles to make the game harder this makes sense, but I felt like these obstacles were more there to just annoy you. Also, I have to mention the part of the game where I fell through, what I thought was the floor, twice... but maybe I am just losing my mind and really it was a hole... maybe. Like I mentioned above the levels were not horrible, some parts of it were enjoyable while others just annoyed me.

The boss battles were easy, at least the ones that I played. This made the bosses rather boring and although they sometimes looked really neat, the interest level slowly grinded to a stop with how easy the bosses were.

This part annoyed me the most. The overmap or what ever you want to call it. The map that you were on when you were searching for other platformer levels to play. This I thought was unnecessary. The game barely tells you were to go and your left searching for the next level or item by yourself. This is fine for rpg's but what's the point of it in a Sonic game? I just want to play the actual levels not go running around looking for the levels. To be fair, I am sure I just made a bunch of stupid moves, and the game actually did send me a lot of hints on were to go and I just missed them. But even if there is a lot of hints in the game. Why do you have to look for levels in the first place?

One point that I want to mention that counters the previous paragraph, is that the overmap stages are relevently small so you might not have as many issues with finding the levels.

So overall the game gets a NO from me. Its not a horrible game. Its an okay game that I would probably spend no more than 5 dollars on.

reviewText:
I missed out on the Dreamcast as a kid, and I can remember that for the longest time I wanted to play the Sonic Adventure games. Thanks to Humble Bundle, I got this version of Sonic Adventure DX for an excellent price. I wasn't sure what to expect. All I knew was that everybody says the Sonic Adventure games are the best 3D Sonic games.

They must have meant Sonic Adventure 2 specifically, because unfortunately (and I don't like saying this), this version of Sonic Adventure DX is nearly unplayable garbage...

Witness the first Sonic wrestling game. In that you'll be wrestling constantly with the camera while it jerks around making you sick. Wrestle with the controls as you try to keep Sonic from running into every wall. Wrestle with your ears as they are screwed by the worst voice acting in a Sonic game I've ever heard. And wrestle with your own disappointment as you watch the game that you had so looked forward to for so many years crumble before your eyes. (Okay, so that last one was a little close to home)

I'm so disappointed. Perhaps it's just this version of Sonic and the original Dreamcast or perhaps even Gamecube versions were better. But this is unacceptable. As far as best 3D Sonic game, I dunno, I was always partial to Sonic Heroes or Unleashed. Either way, it's certainly not this game.

reviewText:
I never played this game when it came out, so as somebody with no nostalgia for it I have to say it has aged quite poorly.

Characters like Sonic, Tails and Knuckles never feel nice to control. They have way too little inertia and just sort of fling themselves across the screen at the slightest tap of the control stick. Like, say you have Sonic running full tilt in the right lane of a city highway, and you see a line of rings coming up in the left lane. It's nearly impossible to change lanes; when you press left Sonic will either immediately make a 90 degree turn and plow into the guardrail, or, if you're lucky, he'll only make a 70 degree turn, still plowing into the guardrail but at least sort of maintaining forward momentum.

The hub worlds that connect the levels are pointlessly large and very boring. There are a bunch of little character arcs with the NPCs that play out as you go through the game, but these are all dull as dishwater, and while there are little character upgrades and hidden tokens scattered throughout, they aren't very hard to find, and when you do find them they don't particularly improve your character. It feels like that stuff was just included because other 3d games were doing similar things, but they never put in the time or effort to make those bits seem meaningful. It's also often very hard to understand where the game wants you to go next.

That said, I enjoy the level design, and while they'd be a lot better if you could actually control things, they have a lot of neat set-pieces and are still kind of fun to run through and explore. It's a game that's constantly on the cusp of being really great. I keep thinking to myself This would be super fun if the controls and camera actually worked
date: if there were more hidden secrets in the overworld and better NPCs." But that's a lot of problems
hoursPlayed: the central formula of the game is good
voteText: but the execution is lackluster at best and at a lot of points it's bad even for the time it was released

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure is a 3D Sonic game. Yup, a 3D Sonic game. They keep making these and they keep hitting the same issues.

Despite this being one of my favourite games on the Dreamcast back in the day, my opinion of game has been tarnished after a recent play through for the Backlog Blitz. Controls are horribly awkward and it feels like you're fighting against the camera angle most of the time. When you're not fighting against the camera angle, you're being sucked into walls or feel like your eyes are melting as the game's orientation warps, zooms and generally hates you throughout.

Gameplay wise you're probably looking at around 7 hours to 100% everyone's story mode, which isn't too bad. Probably even less if you know where you're going and what you're doing.
The game suffers from a slightly vague 'next objective' path - even though it tries to guide you with it's sutble ways.

The one saving grave this game has is the rather decent soundtrack, which I seem to remember being a real strong point throughout Sega games in the 90s.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend going out of the way to play this, but if you're a fan of the Dreamcast and are looking to relive 1999 all over again then this might be for you.
On the plus side the Chao Gardens are still in the game, so you can mess around with those guys for a little while... before you realise how creepy it is.

reviewText: Sonic Adventure has many complaints to its gameplay. Voice acting is overall horrible. The gameplay is broken, bugs and glitches are common, and this is supposed to be a remake. WHY ISN'T IT FIXED!!!!! The launcher won't even work correctly, and the game feels like it's emulated instead of ported. Everything in this game felt lazy and rushed, and can be put next to Sonic 06 in comparison. Sonic Adventure 2 is a much better experience if you want to play a Sonic game. But if it's speed you want, its not here, especially when Big the Cat is fishing.\n\n-------------------------------------->>>>>   5/10

reviewText: I got this game as part of the Sonic Hits Collection, so I went into this game without much of an idea of what it was.  It's a port of a Sega Dreamcast game starring Sonic.  That's pretty much the only good thing I can say about it.\n\nDespite it setting my screen resolution to a 16:9 widescreen (I have a 1280x1024 5:4 screen), the game itself is 4:3, and everything is boxed inside an ugly blue border.  The game didn't recognize my controller, so I was forced to play using my keyboard.  This game, ironically, has better keyboard support than Sonic Generations; all on-screen instructions were translated" to keyboard controls
date: so I didn't have any issues there.\n\nThe game itself simply isn't very good.  The voice acting feels awkward
recommended: as though the actors were shown their scripts word-by-word and had to record the whole game in a single take.  The gameplay switches between decent Sonic platforming (albeit with bad controls -- I'll get to those in a minute) and bad pseudo-adventure gameplay where you run around like a caffinated gopher trying to find the next platforming section.  These "adventure" areas are confusing
hoursPlayed: badly designed (there are invisible walls everywhere)
voteText: and simply un-Sonic-like.  At one point

reviewText:
This game needs some serious help.

Never have I played a game so terrible that I actually could not stand to play it just after I bought it.

People only like it because it gives off nostalgia, and that's no reason to make it look good, because it's not, it's garbage.

Terrible gameplay, so-so graphics, and abysmal soundtrack. The only joy you'll get is from very brief moments of 'fun', but they're too short and far between.

3/10 not nearly as bad as Sonic boom or '06, however.

reviewText: Sonic Adventure DX is all kinds of horrible. No full screen mode even after I select full screen in the configuration. It maxes out at 1024 x 720 resolution, which is fine since it's a Dreamcast game. The camera is shockingly bad. Like, seriously. It's bad. It moves all over on its own. It doesn't move with Sonic. The right analogue stick can move it a little, but seemingly only when stationary and then it switches you to first person but when you pan it doesn't float into a natural first person perspective. I felt a little motion sickness, so I threw in the towel. The controls aren't great either, but I think that's mostly because they're fighting against the camera all the time. It's just an awful game. Maybe it's just a bad port. I never played on Dreamcast.

reviewText:
Sonic Adventure DX is a decent port of the old Dreamcast title. The gameplay is good, but a bit aged now. The music is still fantastic. This was the first game to feature many types of characters with many different types of gameplay and minigames. Overall a nice complete game with many things to do.

For some reason the audio sounds a bit muddy compared to the original Dreamcast version, but most people will probably not notice it.

Except for a few problems. Out of the box, this game has some issues for many users where the configuration tools don't work and gamepads don't work. For most laypeople, this is nothing something that is fixable on their own. Thus, I have to give this and every game in the 4 game Dreamcast Collection" a negative. Sorry
recommended: but you have to make your game run right in order to sell it. An extremely small post-release patch is all I'm asking just to make it so we can set full screen mode and have it keep."

Words can't describe the nostalgia I feel when I play this game. Originally, I played this on the Sega Dreamcast when it first dropped on the market. Every time I play the game again, I feel like I'm back in front of the Dreamcast. DX has been remastered many times, and to see it on PC gets me excited. The graphics are insanely crisp, and the controls are fluent when you play with a gamepad (using a Logitech 360 USB controller for this one). I've always recommended this game throughout the years, but I HIGHLY advise it for PC. This makes a perfect first game" for anyone who hasn't played the Sonic Adventure series. 100/10"

The blue blur speeds into the 3rd dimension for the very first time and the world is hyped! In Sonic Adventure you will be going through multiple story modes for each character that is available with plenty of variety in actions and play styles!\nAll of the storys except 2 that i can name off of my head (cough) knuckles (cough) big (cough) play wonderfully! Sonic and his speed, Amy and her hammer, and Tails and his...well...tails! The story is basic but the gameplay is fun other than that camera that constantly dragged me down into my doom. I give this game 3 dead chaos out of 5!

Definately worth playing. Sonic's stages are fast and open ended. Tails's are fast but linear. Knuckles's stages challenge your searching skills. Omega's are fun shooting galleries. Amy's are nothing spectacular but still enjoyable. To bad you have to play as Big. I hope Steam releases a mod making them optional\nScore: 9.5/10

reviewText: Best game of my childhood, it's like GTA but with no naughty stuff
Graphics and gameplay are very dated but kids seem to love it.

I never played this originally, but if this game was always this bad then I now understand why Dreamcast was a flunk.
I was really hoping to like this game, but it is so unbelievably broken.
Some issues that made getting through even the first area a pain:

FPS skips between 50 and 60 on the fly for no reason, creates serious tearing and artifacting. (I'm playing on a Superclocked 3GB 660 Ti, definitely not my hardware when I run Crysis 3 on Very High/Ultra @60fps).

Camera changes often glitch and change multiple times on turns, and often leave you unable to actually see your path while the camera is changing.

Controls are not responsive or consistent, a small tap left sometimes turns you, then other times will only drift you you slightly left - then you'll hit a corner and you the same small tap does the full turn... wot?
It appears as though your speed effects this, and I have a feeling the FPS is linked with the pysics calculations - creating the issues with the camera changes and random FPS drops. Attack and interact are the same button, very touchy with when it decides you have hit the button for which reason.

Dead spots. The maps are loaded with deadspots. This means you can be within bounds and have your character get stuck inside/behind things. You will have to quit. This happened multiple times while trying to complete just the first level.


As mentioned above, I did not play the original, so I can not determine if this is an extremely poor port or if the game is truly utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. (lol steam bleeping out the word boll ocks)
Here's hoping it's just a bad port, as I know a lot of people are die-hards for this game, and I hope they are able to find a means to play the original game in a manor that is functional.

I will warn you beforehand: This game may be fun, but is flawed. You will be forced to watch the credits roll 7 times (and before you think you can just reset your game to skip them, think again, you will be forced to repeat the last mission for each character if you dont watch the whole credits roll). You will also need to deal with a painstaking camera, which will cause you many cheap deaths. Regardless, this game is fun. You are able to use 6 characters, though Sonic's levels are the longest and have the best level designs. Each character has a unique twist in their gameplay, so there's variety. The game has a fitting music, which are mostly cheese-like guitar riffs. The color palette chosen for the game was appropriate: The characters are colorful, with mostly bright colors. This fits with the lighthearted story, and an overall targeted for a child audience. Doing homing attacks to robots it's fun. The game runs at mostly 60 fps (though you may need to turn some graphic options off depending on your computer, even for an old game). The game will take you around 10 hours, which are mostly fun, though it has some padding and repetitive cutscenes. The game's aesthetic fits this game just fine. The music also improves the whole easygoing feel of the game. The gameplay is kept simple (move, jump, and attack), which suits just fine with this game. Perfect gift for a 10 year old, retro gamers, or any sonic fans. Reccomended if you enjoyed: Sonic adventure 2, sonic heroes, and Sonic Generations.

reviewText:
(inb4 sonic adventure 2 fans come to say how bad SADX is compared to SA2. I really like SADX and I do not like SA2, deal with it.)
This game.
Oh yeah, good old Adventure DX. We all know it. 5 heroes (With the exception of Big he's pretty much useless), different quests, all leading to the same ending. Dramatic moments, suspense, battles with Robotnik/Eggman and plenty of speed. Just everything a 3D Sonic game should have.
But now, let's talk about this port.
As usual, yeah, you got it: It's a cheap Xbox 360 emulation by yours truly, SEGA.
Of course, you got it's glitches; you got the purple borders; you got even new glitches. But you should do like how I do: Ignore these facts and play the game. It's freakin' SONIC ADVENTURE, for God's sakes!
To the game itself, I can easily rate it 9/10. It's a fantastic game, the gameplay is great, the soundtrack is amazing just like in any Sonic game and the story is pretty cleverly done.
To this lazy half-♥♥♥♥♥ port, I'll have to give it a 5/10. It is SADX indeed, but it is also the worst port ever. I'm not saying this out of pure fan opinion"
