This is an unfinished bad game, buy at your own risk.

It tries to bring a lot of new thing to sonic game by making it 3d and adding new mechanics to it, but Sega completely forgot that there were other 3d games by the time it was first launched and decided to reinvent the wheel.

The bad things:

This game is unfinished.
The camera is joke that never will work as intended.
The script is worst than a B movie and the voice actors were even worst, the in game animations are hilarious at best.
The hub world is completely confusing first because of the horrible camera and second because there is absolutely no directions for where you have to go next besides what happened on the cutscenes.
The controls are bad, not unresponsive, they just don't work as intedeed most of the time.
You can enter inside walls quite easily and get out of the quite easily too.
Boss fights are ridiculous repetitive and quite forgettable.
Allmost all the hit box have problems in them.
There are more bad things, it's just that this list is too big already.
The good things:

The level desing is interesting, if it wasn't by all the problems in the engine and bad camera placement it would be a good game to play.
If you want sonic to go fast, just move the stick.Conclusion:

I know that old games must be judged by the time they were made, but this game there were good 3d games launched already in the PC, N64 and PS1 and they could have learned from them, if this was the kind of game Sega was releasing wen it went bankruptcy I can understand the why.

I just recommend that you buy this if you want to play a piece of history of Video Game, or to unlock some Sega Master System and Game Gear Games.
The actual game play is OK if you can get to the levels.\nBut they are broken up by a convoluted nexus" main world and bad boss fights."
DX
I have to play with dumb purple borders or in 1280X720, otherwise it's still Sonic Adventure which sis pretty good.  Gamecube version recommended over this however.

This is proof that some games should just stick to their platforms of origin. I remember Sonic Adventure DX being several hundred times better on the Dreamcast (granted, that was about ten years ago).

This PC port is buggy, the controls lack the responsiveness required to make Sonic feel at all fast, and in an hour of play I had clipped through almost every surface I came into contact with. This is a pity - I was quite excited to get back into one of the few decent Sonic games out there among the myriad of rubbish Sega has polluted its franchise with.

Not even nostalgia can save this one. Thumbs down.

I played this back when it was first released on the Dreamcast, and I still have a lot of fun with it now. The voice acting and cutscenes aren't the best, and some of the camera angles are a bit on the sucky side. Big The Cat's portion of the game is pointless and frustrating, but it's a relatively small part of the game. However, the rest of the characters' gameplay is good, the levels are well-designed, the chao garden is fun to mess around with, and the story is pretty cool. It has a great soundtrack, as well. Overall, it's a good, fun game. I recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, action/adventure platformer to get their mind off of the real world and all of its problems.

Even though this is an old game with more glitches than Sonic 4 E 2 it's still worth it. It is a real adventure running through the hub trying to find something or unlock a stage. Sonic has 10 stages while the rest have 5 except for Big who has 4 in addition to  the perfect Chaos final boss (which is not a spoiler because it's in the opening!). That would be 35 levels in total. the base world for the level is always the same with different challenges for every character. Each character has a unique goal the have to do to complete the stage which keeps the levels very different for each character which can keep you really busy (especially Big's story because his stages were the hardest). The extra mission are challenging as well and once you finish all of them you get to play as Metal Sonic which is pretty rewarding since the only time you see him in the main game is in a tank.

I've been playing this game since I was 11 years old. I've won it countless times, and still I'm not tired of it.

It's not brilliant and it's not hard, but it's certainly entertaining (even if great part of the fun is laughing at their faces in the cutscenes).
The one thing I completely and utterly hate of this game is Big the Cat and his dense fishing levels. There's no fun to listening to the same 20 second loop while some low res fish clips through a pool.

This is no stellar game. It won't give you chills nor make you wish you'd found it sooner... Nevertheless, I'm pretty sure I'll continue playing this game for many years to come. It's simple and fun. Worth around 5 bucks or so though, 8 is a bit steep for it, heheh.

EDIT: Recently, SEGA updated this steam port and it now works as supposed. Changing recomendation to Good. If you plan on buying this beware the glitches and outdated graphics, however with a charming gameplay(for the most part) and amazing music.

Game: Sonic Adventure DX
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Sonic Team/SEGA
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 84/100
Value Score: 8.4/10

• Story: 10/10
o Sonic Adventure DX's storyline takes place mostly in a area within a city named Station Square. One day a institution was being attacked by a strange blue creature who eventually was defeated by Sonic who was near by the area. One event led to another and Sonic found himself on a new journey to defeat Eggman who he finds out is responsible for the blue creature. Eggman is planning to take over the world again with the help of the blue creature who seems to be mysteriously powered up by the chaos emeralds. Sonic and friends must go through their own trials and tribulations to unravel the mystery of the blue creature and the unknown visions that each of them have been having throughout this adventure.

• Characters: 10/10
o Many new and old characters return in this new adventure. Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Eggman and Amy from Sonic CD makes a return to the series already making the game the biggest cast of Sonic characters. Not only them but some new characters have been included such as Chaos the blue creature that accompanies Eggman, Tikal who has a mysterious connection to Knuckles, E-102 Gamma a former robotic minion of eggman, and Big the Cat a new mainstay. Ironically this is also the first Sonic game to include human characters who are nothing more than NPCs but a nice addition to the otherwise barren world that would of been if there werent any. The enemies of the game are completely new with some being a replacement for this 3D adventure which is a nice touch.

• GamePlay: 8/10
o Sonic Adventure DX's gameplay is very different from the usual 2D Sonic games that people have played for years before this game came out. The type of gameplay also varies depending on who you are playing as. In the case of Sonic you have the usual running through stages just like the older games however in 3D view. Some of the other characters you play as include Tails, Knuckles, Big the Cat, Amy and E-102 Gamma who have a alternate type of playstyle such as Tails who mostly tries to catch up to Sonic, Amy who tries to get away from a captor, E-102 Gamma who tries to find a exit or pod to release animals, Big the Cat who's levels are just fishing levels, and Knuckles who looks for 3 crystal shards of the Master Emerald. The characters all have same points of areas to explore however the level design and goal for each is different. Each character has his or her own storyline with their own set of cutscenes and boss battles. By completing each and every storyline will get you the chance to unlock an additional secret story which takes you to the conclusion of the game. Throughout the game you will find powerups for characters which will assist them in their adventures. The gameplay is also similar to any other Sonic game as well such as collecting rings to keep you alive as well. However unlike previous Sonic games, exploration is key to the game and you'll be exploring a majority of the time for certain points of the game or for certain items.

• Graphics: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX's visuals have greatly improved from the older sonic games. It seem like Sega couldnt at first figure out how to make Sonic in 3D after a few failed attempts but it seems like they finally got it right by completely changing the usual art style they have had for the series. The series seem to be pushing more forth a teenage like audience rather than the usual child audience they have been catering too - despite that they managed to maintain the same content they have had for years but bringing a fresh new look. The visuals are quite amazing for its time with the overall world being fully detailed such as in a GTA like game. The character models are also well done and the animation is quite nicely done with a few rough edges here and there but that was mostly because this was the Sonic team's first full attempt at making a full fledged 3D sonic game. Despite that fact even though it has been years since the original game's release and technology has far improved it doesnt seem like Sega had any intention to improve the overall visuals as the game pretty much is the same as it has been since the beginning.

• Sound: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX uses the same sound effects from previous sonic games when breaking a pod or collecting ring but it also includes several new effects thanks to the departure from the 2D landscape to the 3D world. Along with that for the first time the Sonic series now has voice overs for characters which gives a nice touch to the overall storyline. However despite nice additions, some of the voice acting can be pretty unbearable such as Amy's voice but other than that nothing seems too forced.

• Music: 10/10
o Sonic Adventure DX uses a completely new style of music more of a rock/indie rock type themes rather than the traditional industrial type of music that the series has used for quite a while. Along with that there seems to be some pop music added and along with that several vocal tracks for boss battle and character themes. Overall it is one of the best OSTs in the Sonic series.

• Length: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX so far is the longest Sonic game, there are over 5 characters to play as with their own respected storyline, the exploration in the game adds more to the length and you get the additional storyline once you finish all other character's storylines. Overall a decent length for a platformer, this game should take you somewhere between 10-15 hours at the max.

• Replay Value: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX lets you play stages again if you want and also includes a boss battle mode where you can fight against the bosses again. Unlike the previous sonic games where you would have to play the games all over again, you can just go back to the specific area and play that level again depending on who you play as. Of course you are also free to restart a storyline from the beginning without actually having to explore around for powerups.

• Player Value: 8/10
o Sonic Adventure DX is an amazing addition to the Sonic the Hedgehog series. The game has revolutionized the series with its new look, new and expanded gameplay, groundbreaking visuals compared to older games, a decent change to the music, and a well developed storyline that revolves around each and every character with their own role in the storyline. The only main complaint is Sega's lack of work on the PC port - you are gonna have to search up some fixes for the resolution since Sega was too lazy to do an actual decent port of the game. Other than the resolution and window size mistakes, the game is pretty good.

Sonic Adventure DX played just as well as it originally did.  The game is a lot of fun and by far one of the best Sonic games ever made.  There are six (or seven if you count Super Sonic as a separate play style) characters to play as.  Sonic is a really fun character to play as with intense speed and great action.  Tails is fun to fly around as and is very fun to control.  Knuckles is the third fastest character in the game and plays just how he did in Sonic 3 and Knuckles; he can climb walls, run fast, and glide.  He overall is a fun character to play as.  Amy is an all right character to play as.  She isn't that fast, but she controls well.  Big is the only bad character in the game.  He is slow, serves no purpose to the plot, and fishing with him is UNBEARABLE!  E-102 Gamma is my favorite play style out of the bunch.  He may not be as fast as the other characters, but it is fun busting up Badniks with this awesome fighting machine.  This may not be the best Sonic game, but it is certainly my 19th favorite video game.

Let's start off in 1991 with Sega's response to Nintendo's Mario Bros. It was fast, had you running through loop-de-loops at probably the speed of sound. In 1998 in Japan, Sonic Adventure released for the NTSC-J Dreamcast. If you think the old games were fast, this will blow your mind. In 1999, Sonic Adventure International released in America and Japan. It had LOTS of bug fixes, because it was rushed to the Japanese market. In 2003, Sonic Adventure DX released for the GCN and PC. This is the verson I'm reviewing now. This 2011 version has lots of annoyances such as the border, but nevertheless the game is still that classic in 1999. However, I installed BetterSADX, (the mod) which gets rid of the border and installs all the Game Gear minigames that released in the 2003 release but left out in 2011. However, No matter what version, I highly recommend this game. I love this game more than Sonic Unleashed (Xbox 360, PS3). Thanks for reading. 10/10.

One of the best sonic games out there!

A 16 year old game. A 24 year old mascot.

To say I wasn't a SEGA fanboy would be an understatement. I mean, sure, Sonic was the first game I was introduced to, but I was 4 at the time and didn't really understand it. At the age of 15, however, I finally got to play those dreamcast and genesis classics thanks to steam.

So, SONIC ADVENTURE DX. A good game? That depends. How do you like your Sonic games? Do you like running fast and boosting to win? Then go get SONIC GENERATIONS. Looking for a classic 2D Sonic game? Go and get SONIC THE HEDGEHOG 4: EPISODE I/II. Do you want to try out a classic Sonic game that brought the blue blur into the third dimension? Then get this!

With a simple storyline of Eggman (It's Eggman, America. EGGMAN!) trying to take over the world (well, more like Station Square) with a mythical being. He seems to be doing that a lot lately...

Anyway, the game is split into 6 different stories: Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Amy Rose, E-102 Gamma and... *Sigh* Big the cat. Although I haven't completed the game, I've still enjoyed every single part of it, except from the jungle hub. That place is confusing! Each character plays through a portion of the levels, Sonic getting through the most with 10, and most of the others with at most 5. Each character plays smoothly and is easy to control, even Big the Cat, though I find his levels irritating.

Upgrades are scattered around the hub world, allowing for more abilities to be available. These are useful, though some are fairly useless.

Although the game is fun, it hasn't aged well at all. But try it, see whether you like the way 3D Sonic used to play, especially if you are a younger Sonic fan who hasn't experienced those dreamcast titles.

Verdict:

+Solid gameplay
+Outstanding Music
+Responsible for the blue blur and friends getting voices and getting into the third dimension
+Some extra graphical tweaks compared to the standard version

-Can be slow at times with the secondary characters (e.g. Big, Amy, E-102 Gamma, though speed can be reached eventually)
-Glitchy camera (as most platformers have)
-Big the Cat
-More graphical fixes could have been added, considering this is the director's cut.

A Chaos 6/10

P.S. Finish Sonic's story to understand the score :3

If you want to play a game like it was 1999? then this game is the one to bring you back to the past. I personally think that this is one of the classic sonic games out there. Sure Big's stages and story are among the most annoying, but the rest is simply fun and nostalgic.\n\nMinor flaws with the controls, spending more time doing the missions than the story itself, and the emblem collecting sure is a challenge. Either way, I like this game as it is.

The camera angles, man. They're always on point. Just simply perfection. at no point was I ever confused with what the ♥♥♥♥ I was supposed to do next. The game is very clear about what direction you need to be going. simply a flawless masterpiece. 10/10 would clip through the floor and die again.
Some occasional fun, but too bogged down by gameplay glitches, dodgy camera and bland town stages. Good for nostalgia, everyone else avoid.

I'm actually sorry I bought this. It's one of the worst ports I've ever played. The resolution options do NOTHING, aside from changing the size of the borders. The game size is completely locked. I couldn't even get it into fullscreen, the game ignored any changes I made in the configuration.

The game Sonic Adventure is a great game and so is Sonic Aventure DX. But what ever you do, do not get the pc version of this game. When installed, it neglects to create its own registry edit meaning that the configuration file will not be accessible despite it seaming to work. As a result any configurations you make will not be saved. This wouldn't be a problem if the default configurations made any sence but, of course they don't. by default the game will run in window mode with a fixed size. The controls also make no sence having s=jump, d and a=attack, up, down, left, right arrow keys=their corresponding directions, enter=start, q and e=camera controls, and j, k, l, i=look around controls. Even once you manualy make the registry edit, it will not let you change the key bindings. And if you deside to get a controller for the game and get it set up, the buttons will be mapped out wrong and you will automatically look up and left rendering the game unplayable. If you want to play Sonic Adventure, buy if for Dreamcast, GameCube, XBox 360, or PlayStation 3. STAY AWAY FROM THIS PORT! This is the worst port I have ever seen!
Awesome for those that had a Sega Dreamcast

Short version for those of you who've played other versions before: The disc-based PC version will serve you slightly better, and no, there isn't anything new here, but it's certainly serviceable with no new issues to speak of.

Longer version for those of you that haven't played Sonic Adventure: This game was the big leap from the classic 2D Sonic formula to the 3D platforming world, right before the start of the new millennium. This game both reinvented and refined what a Sonic game felt like, and it was quite amazing at the time. Going back, this port doesn't seem to pretend it wasn't a Dreamcast/Gamecube game, everything brought over intact as it originally was. This isn't a problem in most cases, but widescreen users will be quite disappointed to find that you just get a big border around a small square in the middle of the screen. Mods can fix this, but it's a little sad they have to.

The sense of speed is quite impressive, and the 3D environments hammer home for the first time just how completely insane the architecture in Sonic's world (I still call it Mobius) is. This is for the better, especially on ridiculous levels like Speed Highway (a loop-filled highway built between skyscrapers, high above the city) and Windy Valley (tornado debris in the sky forming a chain of floating islands). There are plenty of woah" moments where the camera pans and shows you the whole stretch ahead of you

Sonic Adventure is essential for any Sonic fan. There are many diffent characters to play as with different styles and abilities, the plot intertwines each characters experiences into one huge, amazing story with a little bit of humor, the bosses are challenging but not impossible (Watch out for the Egg Viper, though. I went through almost all 20 of my lives on that thing), and, of course, there's a Chao garden.

Although there are a few glitches and camera issues, which are to be expected from a game this old, they aren't game breaking. You might also want to get BubblegumBalloon's custom config menu so that you can run the game the way you like it (Don't worry, it's free).

Overall, Sonic Adventure is, in my opinion, one of the best Sonic games out there and gets an 8/10 in my book.

goals: get to point A to point B

reviewText: A fun game, but the hub-worlds are obnoxious. Also, BIG THE CAT! Good port.

I never played this original game but I read the comic version of it when it was released later and thoroughly enjoyed that.
I wouldn't judge this game too heavily on being outdated because that's exactly how it should be.
That said, initially, I thought this game wasn't very well designed with the awkward character walking animations and the too-fast controls. However, after getting used to it and playing through it, I realised it was actually a really fun and interesting game.
After getting used to the different characters' attacks etc, I found the gameplay a little easier and sailed through the game, rushing to find out what happens next (JUST LIKE SONIC WOULD).
I never cared much for the Chao Garden features but I'm glad that this was included as it was a nice change from the fast-paced gameplay.
I really liked seeing the same story from different points of view and with each character playing differently, it didn't get boring. I do admit, that there were some well-placed scenes that caused some feels.
I never thought much about playing the newer 3D Sonic games but after this game, I think I will.

A 16 year old game. A 24 year old mascot.

To say I wasn't a SEGA fanboy would be an understatement. I mean, sure, Sonic was the first game I was introduced to, but I was 4 at the time and didn't really understand it. At the age of 15, however, I finally got to play those dreamcast and genesis classics thanks to steam.

So, SONIC ADVENTURE DX. A good game? That depends. How do you like your Sonic games? Do you like running fast and boosting to win? Then go get SONIC GENERATIONS. Looking for a classic 2D Sonic game? Go and get SONIC THE HEDGEHOG 4: EPISODE I/II. Do you want to try out a classic Sonic game that brought the blue blur into the third dimension? Then get this!

With a simple storyline of Eggman (It's Eggman, America. EGGMAN!) trying to take over the world (well, more like Station Square) with a mythical being. He seems to be doing that a lot lately...

Anyway, the game is split into 6 different stories: Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Amy Rose, E-102 Gamma and... *Sigh* Big the cat. Although I haven't completed the game, I've still enjoyed every single part of it, except from the jungle hub. That place is confusing! Each character plays through a portion of the levels, Sonic getting through the most with 10, and most of the others with at most 5. Each character plays smoothly and is easy to control, even Big the Cat, though I find his levels irritating.

Upgrades are scattered around the hub world, allowing for more abilities to be available. These are useful, though some are fairly useless.

Although the game is fun, it hasn't aged well at all. But try it, see whether you like the way 3D Sonic used to play, especially if you are a younger Sonic fan who hasn't experienced those dreamcast titles.

Verdict:

+Solid gameplay
+Outstanding Music
+Responsible for the blue blur and friends getting voices and getting into the third dimension
+Some extra graphical tweaks compared to the standard version

-Can be slow at times with the secondary characters (e.g. Big, Amy, E-102 Gamma, though speed can be reached eventually)
-Glitchy camera (as most platformers have)
-Big the Cat
-More graphical fixes could have been added, considering this is the director's cut.

A Chaos 6/10

P.S. Finish Sonic's story to understand the score :3

I installed this game, hoping it would run smoothly. The problem is, however, that it didn't run at all. It crashed upon startup. So, naturally, I played it on my Xbox 360, because, again; it would NOT run on my computer! I played it on my 360, and it was alright. I'm sure that for the time that this came out in, it was as realistic as it got, and probably pushed their standards a bit. The story could've used some work, as I don't see why you would be racing down corridors to chase villians that were obviously right there in the cutscene, practically taunting at you. The controls were a bit wonky, if you'd move any direction, whoever your current character was would just jerk to aeformentioned direction, without any animation. I'm sure this was due to limitations, but it's such a little detail. Over all, it's a pretty regular Sega Team game.

I never played this original game but I read the comic version of it when it was released later and thoroughly enjoyed that.
I wouldn't judge this game too heavily on being outdated because that's exactly how it should be.
That said, initially, I thought this game wasn't very well designed with the awkward character walking animations and the too-fast controls. However, after getting used to it and playing through it, I realised it was actually a really fun and interesting game.
After getting used to the different characters' attacks etc, I found the gameplay a little easier and sailed through the game, rushing to find out what happens next (JUST LIKE SONIC WOULD).
I never cared much for the Chao Garden features but I'm glad that this was included as it was a nice change from the fast-paced gameplay.
I really liked seeing the same story from different points of view and with each character playing differently, it didn't get boring. I do admit, that there were some well-placed scenes that caused some feels.
I never thought much about playing the newer 3D Sonic games but after this game, I think I will.

Long story short, this version of Sonic Adventure is absolutely terrible. Of all the versions you can purchase, do not get this one. It's a waste of money.

Why is it worse than the Dreamcast Version? The textures are more washed out and lower resolution. The controls are horrendous. The camera is worse. And finally, it's buggy as ♥♥♥♥. I fell through the scenery more than once in the meager time I've played. I've also gotten stuck in walls.

If that doesn't turn you off, let me go into more detail. The controls are absolutely irredeemably bad. Specifically it's the way the analogue stick works. I don't think it's actually analogue. I think they programmed it so you could use the arrow keys to control Sonic and forgot to program a proper analogue stick. So even when you use a controller it's like using a D-pad. Couple this with the terrible camera and the game is nearly unplayable, it'll get stuck behind walls and it whips around violently from time to time which will make it more difficult to control Sonic. Sonic is controlled by which angle he's being looked at by the camera.

To be fair, even when this game was on Dreamcast with better controls and graphics the gameplay was mediocre.

If you want to play a game like it was 1999? then this game is the one to bring you back to the past. I personally think that this is one of the classic sonic games out there. Sure Big's stages and story are among the most annoying, but the rest is simply fun and nostalgic.\n\nMinor flaws with the controls, spending more time doing the missions than the story itself, and the emblem collecting sure is a challenge. Either way, I like this game as it is.

The camera angles, man. They're always on point. Just simply perfection. at no point was I ever confused with what the ♥♥♥♥ I was supposed to do next. The game is very clear about what direction you need to be going. simply a flawless masterpiece. 10/10 would clip through the floor and die again.

Let's start off in 1991 with Sega's response to Nintendo's Mario Bros. It was fast, had you running through loop-de-loops at probably the speed of sound. In 1998 in Japan, Sonic Adventure released for the NTSC-J Dreamcast. If you think the old games were fast, this will blow your mind. In 1999, Sonic Adventure International released in America and Japan. It had LOTS of bug fixes, because it was rushed to the Japanese market. In 2003, Sonic Adventure DX released for the GCN and PC. This is the verson I'm reviewing now. This 2011 version has lots of annoyances such as the border, but nevertheless the game is still that classic in 1999. However, I installed BetterSADX, (the mod) which gets rid of the border and installs all the Game Gear minigames that released in the 2003 release but left out in 2011. However, No matter what version, I highly recommend this game. I love this game more than Sonic Unleashed (Xbox 360, PS3). Thanks for reading. 10/10.

Everyone who played the original Sonic Adventure DX for computer, will easily recognize many buggs. I would really like to see a patch which fixes the buggs. The worst thing is the bugged Audio at some points. But beside of that i really like the graphical update.

In my opinion, despite the ambition (and problems later) this game brought to the franchise, SA1 really hasn't aged well in most regards (especially due to gameplay bugs.) And this lazy port does this fact absolutely no justice either.\n\nPlayable, but your nostalgia for SA1 is going to be your biggest reason for purchasing & playing this. If you own the GameCube version you're better off sticking with it since it's less sloppy. If you have no nostalgia for the Dreamcast and GC/PS2 era though I honestly suggest not bothering with SA1. Yes really.

Game: Sonic Adventure DX
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Sonic Team/SEGA
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 84/100
Value Score: 8.4/10

• Story: 10/10
o Sonic Adventure DX's storyline takes place mostly in a area within a city named Station Square. One day a institution was being attacked by a strange blue creature who eventually was defeated by Sonic who was near by the area. One event led to another and Sonic found himself on a new journey to defeat Eggman who he finds out is responsible for the blue creature. Eggman is planning to take over the world again with the help of the blue creature who seems to be mysteriously powered up by the chaos emeralds. Sonic and friends must go through their own trials and tribulations to unravel the mystery of the blue creature and the unknown visions that each of them have been having throughout this adventure.

• Characters: 10/10
o Many new and old characters return in this new adventure. Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Eggman and Amy from Sonic CD makes a return to the series already making the game the biggest cast of Sonic characters. Not only them but some new characters have been included such as Chaos the blue creature that accompanies Eggman, Tikal who has a mysterious connection to Knuckles, E-102 Gamma a former robotic minion of eggman, and Big the Cat a new mainstay. Ironically this is also the first Sonic game to include human characters who are nothing more than NPCs but a nice addition to the otherwise barren world that would of been if there werent any. The enemies of the game are completely new with some being a replacement for this 3D adventure which is a nice touch.

• GamePlay: 8/10
o Sonic Adventure DX's gameplay is very different from the usual 2D Sonic games that people have played for years before this game came out. The type of gameplay also varies depending on who you are playing as. In the case of Sonic you have the usual running through stages just like the older games however in 3D view. Some of the other characters you play as include Tails, Knuckles, Big the Cat, Amy and E-102 Gamma who have a alternate type of playstyle such as Tails who mostly tries to catch up to Sonic, Amy who tries to get away from a captor, E-102 Gamma who tries to find a exit or pod to release animals, Big the Cat who's levels are just fishing levels, and Knuckles who looks for 3 crystal shards of the Master Emerald. The characters all have same points of areas to explore however the level design and goal for each is different. Each character has his or her own storyline with their own set of cutscenes and boss battles. By completing each and every storyline will get you the chance to unlock an additional secret story which takes you to the conclusion of the game. Throughout the game you will find powerups for characters which will assist them in their adventures. The gameplay is also similar to any other Sonic game as well such as collecting rings to keep you alive as well. However unlike previous Sonic games, exploration is key to the game and you'll be exploring a majority of the time for certain points of the game or for certain items.

• Graphics: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX's visuals have greatly improved from the older sonic games. It seem like Sega couldnt at first figure out how to make Sonic in 3D after a few failed attempts but it seems like they finally got it right by completely changing the usual art style they have had for the series. The series seem to be pushing more forth a teenage like audience rather than the usual child audience they have been catering too - despite that they managed to maintain the same content they have had for years but bringing a fresh new look. The visuals are quite amazing for its time with the overall world being fully detailed such as in a GTA like game. The character models are also well done and the animation is quite nicely done with a few rough edges here and there but that was mostly because this was the Sonic team's first full attempt at making a full fledged 3D sonic game. Despite that fact even though it has been years since the original game's release and technology has far improved it doesnt seem like Sega had any intention to improve the overall visuals as the game pretty much is the same as it has been since the beginning.

• Sound: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX uses the same sound effects from previous sonic games when breaking a pod or collecting ring but it also includes several new effects thanks to the departure from the 2D landscape to the 3D world. Along with that for the first time the Sonic series now has voice overs for characters which gives a nice touch to the overall storyline. However despite nice additions, some of the voice acting can be pretty unbearable such as Amy's voice but other than that nothing seems too forced.

• Music: 10/10
o Sonic Adventure DX uses a completely new style of music more of a rock/indie rock type themes rather than the traditional industrial type of music that the series has used for quite a while. Along with that there seems to be some pop music added and along with that several vocal tracks for boss battle and character themes. Overall it is one of the best OSTs in the Sonic series.

• Length: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX so far is the longest Sonic game, there are over 5 characters to play as with their own respected storyline, the exploration in the game adds more to the length and you get the additional storyline once you finish all other character's storylines. Overall a decent length for a platformer, this game should take you somewhere between 10-15 hours at the max.

• Replay Value: 7/10
o Sonic Adventure DX lets you play stages again if you want and also includes a boss battle mode where you can fight against the bosses again. Unlike the previous sonic games where you would have to play the games all over again, you can just go back to the specific area and play that level again depending on who you play as. Of course you are also free to restart a storyline from the beginning without actually having to explore around for powerups.

• Player Value: 8/10
o Sonic Adventure DX is an amazing addition to the Sonic the Hedgehog series. The game has revolutionized the series with its new look, new and expanded gameplay, groundbreaking visuals compared to older games, a decent change to the music, and a well developed storyline that revolves around each and every character with their own role in the storyline. The only main complaint is Sega's lack of work on the PC port - you are gonna have to search up some fixes for the resolution since Sega was too lazy to do an actual decent port of the game. Other than the resolution and window size mistakes, the game is pretty good.

Now, there are two things to be reviewed:
1°- The game itself
2°- The port (yes, it deserves to be mentioned)

Let's start with the game. Now, Sonic Adventure was released in 1999 for the Dreamcast and, in 2004, it got a remake for the GameCube and PC, entitled Sonic Adventure DX: Director's Cut, the game this port claims to be. At the time, this game was great, with great soundtrack, great level design, great visuals (well, the DX version at least), great gameplay and an all-around great fun. Nowadys, this game is still great, though unfortunally a bit dated. The fact that this game is dated doesn't bother me in the slightest, as this game is very nostalgic for me and I really wanted to replay this, even knowing that it was dated, but the fact that this game is dated may affect some newcomers, as they might be bothered by this game's faults. That's not to say this game is bad nowadays, no, far from that, it's still a great game, though it's now easier to see this game's faults.

Now, to the port. I just have one thing to say about this port, and it is WOW! Just...just wow. To me, it's just incredible the fact that they menaged to do such a port... It's terrible. Why you might ask? Well, they removed half the stuff from DX (including the Game Gear games, WHICH WAS THE REASON I BOUGHT THIS GAME TO BEGIN WITH), didn't fix any glitches (if anything, they added more), removed the option to play in 16:9 widesreen without the use of those purple boarders, made impossible the change of the controls when using the keyboard (which makes your camera spin around like crazy when you're peting your chao, WHICH REALLY PISSES ME OFF), made a configuration tool WHICH DOESNT WORK WITHOUT THE HELP OF THE COMUNITY and they also removed the option to choose the japanease voices. And the fact that it's so bad baffles me

While I still hold a soft spot for this game to this day, I just can't recommend this port for an accurate and likeable SA experience.

Issues I've noticed:

- Textures in many places are outright downgraded
- Sounds are missing
- Gameplay is extremely awkward on keyboard
- Camera issues are even worse than in the original
- Game can only be played with odd 'borders' that you can't rid yourself of.

I was under the assumption that Director's Cuts were supposed to be *upgraded* versions, but DX can hardly be considered that. It's a sloppy port, and not worth grabbing.

5/10

reviewText:
I first played this game about eight or nine years ago on the PC version (before it was released on Steam) and I enjoyed it as much as I still do to this day. I enjoyed playing through the game a second time after getting it on the Steam sale this year alongside childhood favorite, Sonic Adventure 2 (with Battle DLC, because I used to own the SA2:B game on the Nintendo Gamecube).
Sonic's stages are what you'd expect from the fastest hedgehog alive and these have transitioned quite well from the side-scrolling days of the Sega Genesis. They are a blast to play through, if you're used to the PC controls, in which case, you will learn how to play -or fail- rather quickly. Since Tails has always been my favorite Sonic character, I've always found his gameplay to be my favorite. It is one of the more stressful stories to play through, but once you get the hang of how his levels work, it becomes more fun while retaining its challenge. Knuckles' story is all about finding pieces of the Master Emerald, as his gameplay is a treasure hunting game. It's actually kind of fun, and is a nice diversion from the other stories. Amy is one of my least favorite stories in terms of gameplay, but as a character arc, it does some much-needed development for her character. Gamma is actually an enjoyable experience and is the non-Sonic-Tails-Knuckles story that I enjoyed the most. Then, we have Big. I'm gonna be totally honest here, it's not that bad. It's kind of relaxing and was the fastest story for me to complete.
The narrative is, well, very easily subject to opinion. I thought that the story connected all of the characters well enough. Most of the characters do get some great moments and some good character development. Of the six characters, I'd have to say that Tails, Amy, and Gamma get the best of the development (not in any particular order). Sonic is still at some of his best here too, so don't worry about that. Oh, and before I conclude my overly-long review, I should mention that the soundtrack is fantastic. Everything fits in some way and is pretty memorable; it is easily one of the best soundtracks in the Sonic games.
Although, one of the only negatives is that the cutscenes can get really narmy thanks to some very laughable rigging and lip-syncing on the characters. Also Dr. Eggman's I can't believe this!!!" line is something that you'll probably hear so many times over that it will be something you hear in your dreams/nightmares for the rest of your life. It's like Mass Effect's "I will destroy you!" of gaming before that took over as the most annoying thing you'll hear a hundred times in a video game.
Overall
date: this is one of my favorite Sonic games of all time
recommended: and for good reason. If you haven't played it
hoursPlayed: you should give this game and its sequel a shot. Trust me

reviewText: This is a game that people enjoy. Make of that what you will.
Dear SEGA,\n\nDO A REMAKE! PLEASE!
Better than its sequel.\nI don't care much for any other character stories than Sonic's, its the most enjoyable one and the rest are... meh.\nBig the cat is not fun at all, what is the point of him!?
One of the best sonic games out there!

A 16 year old game. A 24 year old mascot.

To say I wasn't a SEGA fanboy would be an understatement. I mean, sure, Sonic was the first game I was introduced to, but I was 4 at the time and didn't really understand it. At the age of 15, however, I finally got to play those dreamcast and genesis classics thanks to steam.

So, SONIC ADVENTURE DX. A good game? That depends. How do you like your Sonic games? Do you like running fast and boosting to win? Then go get SONIC GENERATIONS. Looking for a classic 2D Sonic game? Go and get SONIC THE HEDGEHOG 4: EPISODE I/II. Do you want to try out a classic Sonic game that brought the blue blur into the third dimension? Then get this!

With a simple storyline of Eggman (It's Eggman, America. EGGMAN!) trying to take over the world (well, more like Station Square) with a mythical being. He seems to be doing that a lot lately...

Anyway, the game is split into 6 different stories: Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, Amy Rose, E-102 Gamma and... *Sigh* Big the cat. Although I haven't completed the game, I've still enjoyed every single part of it, except from the jungle hub. That place is confusing! Each character plays through a portion of the levels, Sonic getting through the most with 10, and most of the others with at most 5. Each character plays smoothly and is easy to control, even Big the Cat, though I find his levels irritating.

Upgrades are scattered around the hub world, allowing for more abilities to be available. These are useful, though some are fairly useless.

Although the game is fun, it hasn't aged well at all. But try it, see whether you like the way 3D Sonic used to play, especially if you are a younger Sonic fan who hasn't experienced those dreamcast titles.

Verdict:

+Solid gameplay
+Outstanding Music
+Responsible for the blue blur and friends getting voices and getting into the third dimension
+Some extra graphical tweaks compared to the standard version

-Can be slow at times with the secondary characters (e.g. Big, Amy, E-102 Gamma, though speed can be reached eventually)
-Glitchy camera (as most platformers have)
-Big the Cat
-More graphical fixes could have been added, considering this is the director's cut.

A Chaos 6/10

P.S. Finish Sonic's story to understand the score :3

After clearing all characters and killing the TRUE final boss, I noticed that my Super Sonic achievement didn't pop. While that irritated me, it's really the only major issue i've had with the game. The game, in my opinion, is a solid 7.5 out of 10. It's worth the couple dollars in the Steam store, and ABSOLUTELY worth $1 in a Humble Bundle.

Even though this is an old game with more glitches than Sonic 4 E 2 it's still worth it. It is a real adventure running through the hub trying to find something or unlock a stage. Sonic has 10 stages while the rest have 5 except for Big who has 4 in addition to  the perfect Chaos final boss (which is not a spoiler because it's in the opening!). That would be 35 levels in total. the base world for the level is always the same with different challenges for every character. Each character has a unique goal the have to do to complete the stage which keeps the levels very different for each character which can keep you really busy (especially Big's story because his stages were the hardest). The extra mission are challenging as well and once you finish all of them you get to play as Metal Sonic which is pretty rewarding since the only time you see him in the main game is in a tank.

I will warn you beforehand: This game may be fun, but is flawed. You will be forced to watch the credits roll 7 times (and before you think you can just reset your game to skip them, think again, you will be forced to repeat the last mission for each character if you dont watch the whole credits roll). You will also need to deal with a painstaking camera, which will cause you many cheap deaths. Regardless, this game is fun. You are able to use 6 characters, though Sonic's levels are the longest and have the best level designs. Each character has a unique twist in their gameplay, so there's variety. The game has a fitting music, which are mostly cheese-like guitar riffs. The color palette chosen for the game was appropriate: The characters are colorful, with mostly bright colors. This fits with the lighthearted story, and an overall targeted for a child audience. Doing homing attacks to robots it's fun. The game runs at mostly 60 fps (though you may need to turn some graphic options off depending on your computer, even for an old game). The game will take you around 10 hours, which are mostly fun, though it has some padding and repetitive cutscenes. The game's aesthetic fits this game just fine. The music also improves the whole easygoing feel of the game. The gameplay is kept simple (move, jump, and attack), which suits just fine with this game. Perfect gift for a 10 year old, retro gamers, or any sonic fans. Reccomended if you enjoyed: Sonic adventure 2, sonic heroes, and Sonic Generations.

I played this back when it was first released on the Dreamcast, and I still have a lot of fun with it now. The voice acting and cutscenes aren't the best, and some of the camera angles are a bit on the sucky side. Big The Cat's portion of the game is pointless and frustrating, but it's a relatively small part of the game. However, the rest of the characters' gameplay is good, the levels are well-designed, the chao garden is fun to mess around with, and the story is pretty cool. It has a great soundtrack, as well. Overall, it's a good, fun game. I recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, action/adventure platformer to get their mind off of the real world and all of its problems.

I never played this originally, but if this game was always this bad then I now understand why Dreamcast was a flunk.
I was really hoping to like this game, but it is so unbelievably broken.
Some issues that made getting through even the first area a pain:

FPS skips between 50 and 60 on the fly for no reason, creates serious tearing and artifacting. (I'm playing on a Superclocked 3GB 660 Ti, definitely not my hardware when I run Crysis 3 on Very High/Ultra @60fps).

Camera changes often glitch and change multiple times on turns, and often leave you unable to actually see your path while the camera is changing.

Controls are not responsive or consistent, a small tap left sometimes turns you, then other times will only drift you you slightly left - then you'll hit a corner and you the same small tap does the full turn... wot?
It appears as though your speed effects this, and I have a feeling the FPS is linked with the pysics calculations - creating the issues with the camera changes and random FPS drops. Attack and interact are the same button, very touchy with when it decides you have hit the button for which reason.

Dead spots. The maps are loaded with deadspots. This means you can be within bounds and have your character get stuck inside/behind things. You will have to quit. This happened multiple times while trying to complete just the first level.


As mentioned above, I did not play the original, so I can not determine if this is an extremely poor port or if the game is truly utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. (lol steam bleeping out the word boll ocks)
Here's hoping it's just a bad port, as I know a lot of people are die-hards for this game, and I hope they are able to find a means to play the original game in a manor that is functional.

The pinnacle of Sonic on Steam, this is a classic 3D platformer that originated on Dreamcast, then was ported to Gamecube, then XBOX 360 and PS3, and finally Steam. And it holds up! ..Somewhat. The default controls suck absolute ♥♥♥, making the game unplayable if you don't have a controller. The camera can be jarring, but nothing that can't be solved with a rotate of camera. The voice acting is hilariously campy in all the right ways, but the sync is awful. The HD graphics improve the textures and graphics, but add this weird shiny lighting that make all characters look like wet plastic. The gameplay holds up well and the levels have great design and replayablility. Plus, the Chao garden will keep you coming back for more. Easily, one of the most perfect Sonic games in a not-so perfect port.

This was one of my favourite games on the Dreamcast. Played it and SA2 endlessly. I thought since I loved it then, I'd go back and have a go at it again. I have to say, in some senses, it has stood the test of time. It may be just nostalgia talking, but the story line was still compelling, (even after having played it through in its entirety at least 5 times as a kid) and the gameplay itself was still relatively challenging and fun. I particularily enjoyed the E102-y storyline. It was much darker than I remembered.

However, I did forget about the glitchy gameplay and clunky controls. Changing view is difficult, sometimes you come up against invisible obstacles, and the game seems throw wierd things at you in general. Like holes in the texture corners. Also sometimes you can run on top of trees in the mystic ruins.

Overall, fun. A good dose of childhood feels for those of us that played it before.

I do hope you like unskippable credits, though. You'll have to watch the same ones 7 times by the proper end" of the game."

I've always been a fan of the Sonic the Hedgehog series and how can you not say it's a classic. At the time this game had amazing graphics that were ahead of time. In case you need an Idea of how amazing the game looked, Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time came out the same year this game was released in Japan. The main story is a bit cheap and a bit overdone but that doesn't take away from the quick on the feet Sonic the Hedgehog. This game also gives you 5 other side stories that includes old favorites like Tails and Knuckles. The game is a quick playthrough and could be completed within a day or two but the replay value is abundant. You can replay the levels and go for the best time, complete missions, listen to a unique and awesome soundtrack, and take care of little pets called Chao. This game is an original and with the 7.99 price tag it is way more than worth the buy. I recommend any Sonic fan, young or veteran, to pick this game up on Steam today and enjoy this one of a kind Classic.

I'm actually sorry I bought this. It's one of the worst ports I've ever played. The resolution options do NOTHING, aside from changing the size of the borders. The game size is completely locked. I couldn't even get it into fullscreen, the game ignored any changes I made in the configuration.

The game Sonic Adventure is a great game and so is Sonic Aventure DX. But what ever you do, do not get the pc version of this game. When installed, it neglects to create its own registry edit meaning that the configuration file will not be accessible despite it seaming to work. As a result any configurations you make will not be saved. This wouldn't be a problem if the default configurations made any sence but, of course they don't. by default the game will run in window mode with a fixed size. The controls also make no sence having s=jump, d and a=attack, up, down, left, right arrow keys=their corresponding directions, enter=start, q and e=camera controls, and j, k, l, i=look around controls. Even once you manualy make the registry edit, it will not let you change the key bindings. And if you deside to get a controller for the game and get it set up, the buttons will be mapped out wrong and you will automatically look up and left rendering the game unplayable. If you want to play Sonic Adventure, buy if for Dreamcast, GameCube, XBox 360, or PlayStation 3. STAY AWAY FROM THIS PORT! This is the worst port I have ever seen!

Sonic Adventure is essential for any Sonic fan. There are many diffent characters to play as with different styles and abilities, the plot intertwines each characters experiences into one huge, amazing story with a little bit of humor, the bosses are challenging but not impossible (Watch out for the Egg Viper, though. I went through almost all 20 of my lives on that thing), and, of course, there's a Chao garden.

Although there are a few glitches and camera issues, which are to be expected from a game this old, they aren't game breaking. You might also want to get BubblegumBalloon's custom config menu so that you can run the game the way you like it (Don't worry, it's free).

Overall, Sonic Adventure is, in my opinion, one of the best Sonic games out there and gets an 8/10 in my book.

This game defined some of my childhood; back when I was around 10/11 years old.
I remember playing this game on the gamcube version and I absolutely loved it.

Looking back at this game and playing it now, there is A LOT of flaws in the physics of the game, and there are plenty of glitched to go around. Not to mention... the voice acting and lip syncing. Good god.
Though, in all honesty, the moment when the physics break, or when the voice acting is horendous, it makes the game a little more enjoyable. I tend to get a good laugh out of it, rather than being frustrated at it. Though maybe there are times where if the game breaks at a dire situation, I would call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

Other than that, the main positives I can give this game is the story, and (obviously) the chao garden. I remember spending countless hours on the chao garden just taking care of those cute little creatures and it was really relaxin; like I was taking a little break from so much action from the game. The story was interesting too, and at moments it got quite tear jerking. (Especially with E-102 GAMMA, but I wont spoil it here). Big the Cat's missions were kind of slow, but playing it now, I kind of like the slow pace of fishing. Like the chao garden, it gives you a sort of break from the rest of the story; and I guess maybe that's what the developers were kind of going for.

Overall I would give the game a 8/10. Though there are major flaws, they can really just be either overlooked, or just make the game a little more enjoyable at times. :)
Tails is the best part :D\nThe Chao garden is great too :D!!!
Why did I play this game.

Sonic, Tails, and Knuckles' stories are pretty fun. Gamma is unique enough to get by on novelty. Big and Amy's stories are cancer but thankfully hardly last longer than 20 minutes apiece. Overall worth playing if you like 3D platformers and want to experience one of the earlier ones to see what was done right and what was done wrong in the onset of 3D gaming. Or just for fun, it's pretty good at that too.

I could just keep on playing this game and NOT get tired of it! It's fantastic! Yes it can be a little buggy, yes the cutsences are.......eww, yes the voice acting it's kinda a hit and miss, and yes. Big the Cat sucks hard. BUT! If you can get pass all of that, and enjoy the levels, enjoy the music, enjoy the character's storys (Except Big's), and enjoy the gameplay on what this game has to offer (Except Big's). Then you got you're self a fantastic Sonic game- NO! A fantastic Video Game.\n\nI am not afraid to give this game a 10/10. Get this game along with the classic games NOW! It's a great game and definitely worth you're time.

Now, there are two things to be reviewed:
1°- The game itself
2°- The port (yes, it deserves to be mentioned)

Let's start with the game. Now, Sonic Adventure was released in 1999 for the Dreamcast and, in 2004, it got a remake for the GameCube and PC, entitled Sonic Adventure DX: Director's Cut, the game this port claims to be. At the time, this game was great, with great soundtrack, great level design, great visuals (well, the DX version at least), great gameplay and an all-around great fun. Nowadys, this game is still great, though unfortunally a bit dated. The fact that this game is dated doesn't bother me in the slightest, as this game is very nostalgic for me and I really wanted to replay this, even knowing that it was dated, but the fact that this game is dated may affect some newcomers, as they might be bothered by this game's faults. That's not to say this game is bad nowadays, no, far from that, it's still a great game, though it's now easier to see this game's faults.

Now, to the port. I just have one thing to say about this port, and it is WOW! Just...just wow. To me, it's just incredible the fact that they menaged to do such a port... It's terrible. Why you might ask? Well, they removed half the stuff from DX (including the Game Gear games, WHICH WAS THE REASON I BOUGHT THIS GAME TO BEGIN WITH), didn't fix any glitches (if anything, they added more), removed the option to play in 16:9 widesreen without the use of those purple boarders, made impossible the change of the controls when using the keyboard (which makes your camera spin around like crazy when you're peting your chao, WHICH REALLY PISSES ME OFF), made a configuration tool WHICH DOESNT WORK WITHOUT THE HELP OF THE COMUNITY and they also removed the option to choose the japanease voices. And the fact that it's so bad baffles me

the steam version of this game is terrible!
for starters, the game will fight you against leaving the game full screen, the configuration tool doesn't really serve any purpose as it doesn't help with anything but keyboard configuration ( assuming it saves your custom layout )
also the configuration tricks you into thinking the game didn't recognize your gamepad, when in reality it's working and the game will have no problem with it
screen resolution is pitiful, highest resolution possible is 1280x720 and 1/4 of the screen is a border around the game, because it doesn't even have widescreen support and as I said before, full screen is impossible to get ( and even so would still be 1280x720 )
this seems to be a direct port of the gamecube version, but Jesus, Sega, you could at least have TRIED to make it functional
or at the very least, worth the price.

if you want to try this game, I'd much rather recommend you getting a gamecube emulator ( dolphin ) and the iso for it and play it there, this version is NOT worth your money ( and hey, sega's cheating on us with such a terrible port, a little emulation for a decent experience won't hurt )

Sonic Adventure! I remember this game and I had great fun playing it on my Dreamcast! Too bad my memory couldn't stay that way. But no matter what kind of controller I use with this game, they...remain too sensitive. I guess I could get pass that sooner or later but the downer of this game is... it was cutting edge at it's time but now it's... simple. Somehow I just can't get into it anymore after playing crazy games like Boarderlands and Serious Sam 3 or any of the Half-Life games. After those games Sonic Adventure DX feels like it got dumbed down, but it hasn't. I somehow grew out of it. I'm even getting stuck on the same level now that I first got stuck on it when I owned it the first time. It's been that long since I've played it. Don't get me wrong, this was a great game when it first came out and I still consider it a great game... for... kids. Young ones at that. Nice thing about this classic is it's actually some of the very few games that are great for kids if you want them to have fun playing video games without the brutal life-like violence most games have now-a-days. I definitely recommend for kids because us older ones have definitely been ruined and spoiled by our extreme games.

I first played this game about eight or nine years ago on the PC version (before it was released on Steam) and I enjoyed it as much as I still do to this day. I enjoyed playing through the game a second time after getting it on the Steam sale this year alongside childhood favorite, Sonic Adventure 2 (with Battle DLC, because I used to own the SA2:B game on the Nintendo Gamecube).
Sonic's stages are what you'd expect from the fastest hedgehog alive and these have transitioned quite well from the side-scrolling days of the Sega Genesis. They are a blast to play through, if you're used to the PC controls, in which case, you will learn how to play -or fail- rather quickly. Since Tails has always been my favorite Sonic character, I've always found his gameplay to be my favorite. It is one of the more stressful stories to play through, but once you get the hang of how his levels work, it becomes more fun while retaining its challenge. Knuckles' story is all about finding pieces of the Master Emerald, as his gameplay is a treasure hunting game. It's actually kind of fun, and is a nice diversion from the other stories. Amy is one of my least favorite stories in terms of gameplay, but as a character arc, it does some much-needed development for her character. Gamma is actually an enjoyable experience and is the non-Sonic-Tails-Knuckles story that I enjoyed the most. Then, we have Big. I'm gonna be totally honest here, it's not that bad. It's kind of relaxing and was the fastest story for me to complete.
The narrative is, well, very easily subject to opinion. I thought that the story connected all of the characters well enough. Most of the characters do get some great moments and some good character development. Of the six characters, I'd have to say that Tails, Amy, and Gamma get the best of the development (not in any particular order). Sonic is still at some of his best here too, so don't worry about that. Oh, and before I conclude my overly-long review, I should mention that the soundtrack is fantastic. Everything fits in some way and is pretty memorable; it is easily one of the best soundtracks in the Sonic games.
Although, one of the only negatives is that the cutscenes can get really narmy thanks to some very laughable rigging and lip-syncing on the characters. Also Dr. Eggman's I can't believe this!!!" line is something that you'll probably hear so many times over that it will be something you hear in your dreams/nightmares for the rest of your life. It's like Mass Effect's "I will destroy you!" of gaming before that took over as the most annoying thing you'll hear a hundred times in a video game.
Overall

reviewText: One of my favorite sonic games of all time

This game is one of my favorites. While as broken as it is by today's standards, this game is great for anyone willing to take a trip down Nostalgia Lane, or wanting to check out the first 3D Sonic game (not including the Travelers Tales games). The camera is ♥♥♥♥, the acting is terrible, and the gameplay is just as broken as before. Not recommended for anyone looking for a good platformer, but if you loved the Dreamcast and/or Gamecube versions, this is one spot on port.

I dont normally write reviews but i couldnt help it with this one. This game has so much nostalgia for me and getting to play it again on pc after so many years was just amazing. This game has so much potential and does deliver. Sonic adventure DX   has a great story, lots  of replay ability for both the story and the fact of there being so many Emblems to get after the main game in you so chose to 100% the game. Another great part of this game is being able to raise chao and race them. Sonic adventure DX also have a awesome sound track from the intro theme to the character themes I would give the sound track a 7 out of 10. Aside from all that you got good stage desgin and graphics. The only complaint I have on this game is that the Camera not the best in the world i found that i had a hard time seeing my character on the one of the stages however personally i would not  let that get you to discourage as the Camera sistuation is only minor an not a huge issue.
